item.title: Around-the-World Packing List
item.description: I've had a lot of people ask what we packed for our trip. Today I stumbled upon this list and decided to post it to help any one else who is packing for an around-the-world trip, as well as for future me. This list includes everything we needed from the beaches of Thailand to the sub-zero temperatures of Nepal. We picked things up and left things behind, so this is an aggregate list of everything we needed at some point. The only things not listed are Mark's clothes, which I could probably list
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: I've had a lot of people ask what we packed for our trip. Today I stumbled upon this list and decided to post it to help any one else who is packing for an around-the-world trip, as well as for future me. This list includes everything we needed from the beaches of Thailand to the sub-zero temperatures of Nepal. We picked things up and left things behind, so this is an aggregate list of everything we needed at some point. The only things not listed are Mark's clothes, which I could probably list from memory because I saw him in the same 5 shirts for over a year. The world in general is much more modest than the US (can't show your knees in Africa, no tank tops or shorts in rural Asia, 3-piece outfit required in Bangladesh...), something I quickly learned and adjusted my pack to. MISCELLANEOUS: 60L backpacking bag and rain-cover small fold-up daypack 40 degree sleeping bag mosquito net (we used this a lot) phone (to use with sim cards and listen to music) earbuds iPad (for blog writing) camera chargers Steripen (to sterilize water - we used this daily.) head lamp batteries waterproof watch deck of cards notebook & pen money belt - driver's license, passport, credit card, ATM card copies of documents and cards for backpack diving logs, diving card (for scuba) sunglasses TOILETRIES: toothbrush & toothpaste travel size shampoo, conditioner, soap (refilled as we went) deodorant quick-dry towel (very small) razor comb toilet paper (this is key) DIVA cup travel size bug spray travel size sunscreen hand sanitizer tiger-balm (to put under your nose if stuck in a place with bad smells for days) hair ties ear plugs (for loud overnight bus rides) tweezers nail clippers MEDICINE: very basic 1st aid kit, pack of electrolyte powder (for bad digestive issues) pills - birth control, malaria, cipro, Ibuprofen, high altitude medicine, motion sickness medicine CLOTHES: down jacket rain jacket gloves, snow pants (for Everest basecamp) thermal long-sleeve 3 T-shirts 2 tank tops capri yoga pants leggings knee-length skirt athletic shorts floor-length black skirt (for temples, churches, etc.) black loose athletic pants (for modest countries) traditional 3-piece outfit (purchased in Bangladesh, also used in India) 2 dresses - 1 modest pashmina scarf hat 3 pairs of socks (one extra warm) 1 swimsuit 4 pairs of quick-dry underwear 2 sports bras, 1 bra SHOES: Chaco sandals (waterproof, good for hiking, durable) flat Target sandals (to look nicer) hiking boots

item.title: The Obligatory Reflection - Boulder, CO
item.description: After almost a month of being back, it's time for the obligatory end-of-trip reflection. As my great friend Hannah said, "I'm excited to observe and see how travel changed you". While that makes me feel a bit like a lab rat, I have to agree that I am curious to see how I have grown. item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: After almost a month of being back, it's time for the obligatory end-of-trip reflection. As my great friend Hannah said, "I'm excited to observe and see how travel changed you". While that makes me feel a bit like a lab rat, I have to agree that I am curious to see how I have grown. A few things I know I have learned so far are that: I LOVE free bathrooms that are not covered in spiders and bugs coming up through the hole an empty cement room with a trough on one end door-less and TP-less so stinky I almost pass out If Mark and I made it through one year of being together 24/7, along with various digestive and other unflattering issues, I am very optimistic for our future. I am very assertive. It must be something about people trying to scam you, creepy men, bargaining, and having to deal with different issues daily, but I now don't take crap from anyone. Watch out! We are really lucky to be from the USA. We maintain a much higher standard of living than the rest of the world. We don't have thousands of soldiers walking around town with fingers on gun triggers, we don't live in mud huts, and we have endless opportunities to guide our lives in the direction that makes us happiest. It is important to remember how blessed we are, and to give generously to those who aren't as lucky. Travel is worth every penny. It's true we would be MUCH better off financially if we hadn't done this trip, but we have absolutely no regrets spending it all. --- Our favorite countries (although we disagree on the order) are Myanmar, Nepal, and Bangladesh. Our least favorite was India (due to our interactions with the people - although we were only in the big cities). Although they did have some of the best food. Our favorite foods came from Mexico, India, and Israel. The worst food was in Myanmar (Funny how Myanmar/India were exact opposites when it comes to food versus overall awesomeness). The country that was hardest to communicate in was Brazil. The coolest language was Ethiopian - google it, it's crazy. Now that we have more-or-less settled into our Boulder condo, we have exciting life news (...no, we are not pregnant). I have decided to go to a 6-month website development school on Pearl Street. There's a guaranteed job at the end, and I am so excited to learn something new! Also, Mark just accepted an excellent big-boy job at Seagate, a big hard drive company near home. Hello, real world! Anyways, that's the best reflection I can do right now. Time to chug a coffee and continue preparing our 2013 taxes :) Excited to see all of you (in person) soon!!

item.title: Home Again, Home Again, Jiggedy Jig! - Denver, CO
item.description: We had planned to surprise our parents by having our siblings invite them to dinner at the same restaurant. We told them we would arrive three days later, so we were looking forward to seeing their shocked faces when we walked in. The flight from Corpus Christi to Dallas was delayed but worked out fine. Our flight from Dallas to Denver, however, was diverted to land at Colorado Springs due to bad weather closing DIA. We joined a slew of other planes there, waiting for the hourly update to hear
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We had planned to surprise our parents by having our siblings invite them to dinner at the same restaurant. We told them we would arrive three days later, so we were looking forward to seeing their shocked faces when we walked in. The flight from Corpus Christi to Dallas was delayed but worked out fine. Our flight from Dallas to Denver, however, was diverted to land at Colorado Springs due to bad weather closing DIA. We joined a slew of other planes there, waiting for the hourly update to hear if DIA was open. Finally, three hours and a federally required "extended delay" snack later, we flew to DiA. We were forced to call the parents and tell them we were in Colorado but the dinner was off. Major bummer. Of course the day we returned to Denver was the only time we have ever been significantly delayed on our trip. Go figure. Anyways, we got picked up, grabbed a Chipotle (mine was free because the guy was so impressed we came straight there from the airport), and went to Matt and Emily's new house (my brother and his wife) to hang out with everyone and eat dessert. It was a stressful and disappointing day, but in the end we were so happy to be able to see our famlilies. Mark and I have started moving and also begun the job/school hunt. It's good to be home :) Domesticated life here we come!

item.title: Where Everything's Bigger - Corpus Christi, Texas, United States
item.description: We took the last few days of our trip to visit Mark's brother, Brad, and his girlfriend, Camilia. Checking our bag in Mazatlan earned us a fee. At least we only have one now! I was also not allowed to carry my new tortilla press onto the plane...in Mexico. Something about it being a weapon. We were only given soft-drinks on our international flight from Mazatlan to Dallas. American Airlines, and airlines in America in general, are the worst in the world. Immigration at the Dallas airport was
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded:
We took the last few days of our trip to visit Mark's brother, Brad, and his girlfriend, Camilia. Checking our bag in Mazatlan earned us a fee. At least we only have one now! I was also not allowed to carry my new tortilla press onto the plane...in Mexico. Something about it being a weapon. We were only given soft-drinks on our international flight from Mazatlan to Dallas. American Airlines, and airlines in America in general, are the worst in the world. Immigration at the Dallas airport was (ironically) the least organized we have seen in our whole year traveling. Hoards of people, confusion, hours in line, and unfriendly faces were our warm welcome back to the USA. We met a famous boxing announcer and spent time chatting until I noticed he was taking (what he thought were) indiscreet photos of me on his phone. I called him out and made him delete them. Then Mark lost his Colorado hat (that he had somehow held on to the whole year) in the Corpus Christi airport. But the day wasn't all bad. Our long layover in Dallas meant that we had time to scarf down Qdoba burritos (Chipotle has to wait until Colorado). Mark re-filled his coke with a giant smile on his face - he's been looking forward to bottomless soda for months. We also drank from water fountains, used provided toilet paper, and washed our hands with warm water. Go America! After a day of flying it was great to see Brad and Camilia! Brad had a serious burn accident at work (he is a mechanic) a few months ago. He is sporting some serious wounds that are not done healing, but is doing much, much better. We relaxed at their house, did some chores (like write this blog), saw the new house they just bought nearby (it's still being constructed but is the best looking on the block), and cooked a mean taco meal with our new tortilla press. I gained back most of the weight lost on the trip. It was a good intro back to America. Our last night we went to the new Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie. Or as one article I agree with put it, "The Megan Fox Show". Other than her face always being on the screen in a model pout, it was pretty wonderful. Next stop Boulder!
Finally...A Tex-Mex Burrito...Yum
Free refills!
Reunited

item.title: 2 Year Wedding Anniversary - Mazatlán, Sinaloa, Mexico
item.description: Due to all Mazatlan hostels and hotels being full of vacationing Mexicans, Mark and I found an Airbnb in the spare room of a woman's house. She was friendly, gave us towels for the beach, mangos, and a delicious homemade breakfast of mango smoothie, yogurt, tortillas, rice, beans, and veggies. Yum. The city used to have dozens of cruise ships stop daily, but after the reputation in the area for drugs, the tourism stopped. Recently things have been picking up again, especially as a place for
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded:
Due to all Mazatlan hostels and hotels being full of vacationing Mexicans, Mark and I found an Airbnb in the spare room of a woman's house. She was friendly, gave us towels for the beach, mangos, and a delicious homemade breakfast of mango smoothie, yogurt, tortillas, rice, beans, and veggies. Yum. The city used to have dozens of cruise ships stop daily, but after the reputation in the area for drugs, the tourism stopped. Recently things have been picking up again, especially as a place for locals to come on holiday. It's a nice city with a cute main square and goofy matching boxy giant golf cart-like taxis. Our day and night in Mazatlan also happened to be exactly on our 2-year wedding anniversary. To celebrate we relaxed at the beach, walked around town, showered, watched Mythbusters, ate nachos, and went to a shfancy restaurant (El Presidio) recommended to us by Mark's cousin. It was set in a re-done abandoned building, with a beautiful courtyard full of lights and vines. One of the prettiest places I have ever eaten. The food was delicious, and brought to the table in bird cages. Yes, bird cages. Very hipster-classy of them. We ate so much that we almost puked.
Picnic
Stoked
Sandy Hair

item.title: Culiacan - Culiacán Rosales, Sinaloa, Mexico
item.description: From Queretaro we bussed back to Mexico City to catch a flight to Culiacan. You've probably heard about it in the news for its drug problems? My Aunt Blanca, Uncle Dave, and cousins (David and Ximena) live there. But they are not drug lords (I don't think). It was great to be around familiar sights and faces again. It was like a vacation from a vacation. David and Ximena had a baby girl, Danika, about a year ago. Probably the cutest and toughest girl you'll ever see. And last but not least -
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded:
From Queretaro we bussed back to Mexico City to catch a flight to Culiacan. You've probably heard about it in the news for its drug problems? My Aunt Blanca, Uncle Dave, and cousins (David and Ximena) live there. But they are not drug lords (I don't think). It was great to be around familiar sights and faces again. It was like a vacation from a vacation. David and Ximena had a baby girl, Danika, about a year ago. Probably the cutest and toughest girl you'll ever see. And last but not least - Jayden. He's my cousin Bianca's kid. I guess that makes him a first cousin once removed? We had a debate about it. They were all incredible hosts, making sure we got every taste of Mexico possible. The first day we spent eating. And not much else. Ceviche, raspados (Mexican snow cones), and pizza. Raspados make American snow cones look like baby food. These suckers are loaded up with all sorts of options. Fresh fruit juice, coconut, and dulce de leche to name a few. Then they soak the top with condensed milk. Mmm... mmm.... diabetes. After, we ate pizza at a restaurant overlooking the city and mountains. Here we saw one of (if not) the best sunsets I've seen in my life. Even the kitchen staff took a break from making pizza to come out and watch it. Unfortunately we forgot the camera, leaving you with a cell phone picture. The next morning we had yet another incredible meal and my Aunt and Uncle's house. Chilaquiles. And later that afternoon they took us to Altata, a small town on the coast where a lot of Mexicans go for spring break. They have a beach house there that I visited a lot growing up. It was fun showing Laura part of my childhood and reminiscing. Except the mosquitos. I conveniently forgot about them. We ate an awesome seafood dinner on the boardwalk and took a boat out into the Sea of Cortez where we saw some dolphins! The rest of our stay included more incredible food. Mainly tacos. Carnitas, goat, innards, head, seafood. If it's a meat, we probably ate it in a taco. David and Ximena also bought us a tortilla maker so we can make fresh corn tortillas for tacos at home! Turns out it's not that hard. After a few crispified tortillas we had it down to an art. We also relaxed at the neighborhood pool a few times and went to a local soccer game. It was a tie game, but we had fun hanging out drinking Tacate. Nights were spent playing competitive games of Monopoly and Apples to Apples and drinking margaritas. Overall, life was very good and as Uncle Dave would say, "Welcome to semi-civilization!"
Family Boat
Goat Tacos!
Adorable Danika
Altata House
Dolphins with Birds
Altata - Freshest Seafood
Happy Family
Beautiful Sunset

item.title: Queretaro - Queretaro, Mexico
item.description: We bussed from the Queretaro bus station to our hostel, dropped off our things, then went out for some late night tacos. Absolutely delicious. I don't think Mexican tacos could ever get old. Then we fell asleep. In our dorm room...not at the taco stand. Our hostel, the Blue Bicycle, is run by three middle-aged women and is spotless. There is a terrace overlooking the city, hot showers, towels, a delicious breakfast, free bicycle rentals, and the whole thing is new and beautiful. We are so glad
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded:
We bussed from the Queretaro bus station to our hostel, dropped off our things, then went out for some late night tacos. Absolutely delicious. I don't think Mexican tacos could ever get old. Then we fell asleep. In our dorm room...not at the taco stand. Our hostel, the Blue Bicycle, is run by three middle-aged women and is spotless. There is a terrace overlooking the city, hot showers, towels, a delicious breakfast, free bicycle rentals, and the whole thing is new and beautiful. We are so glad we went. Mark found a walking tour map of the historic center, and became "Tour-guide Mark" for the day. We saw a dozen churches, a dozen plazas, and lots of cool artisanal things. Lunch was delicious tortas (sandwiches filled with meat, cheese, and salsa). We also saw a group exercise session in the park, which looked more like a native dance. People danced to one loud drum, wore noisemakers on their legs, and spun in semi-coordinated unison. It was extremely entertaining. The city is beautiful and green and old (in a good way). Well, at least the part we are in. It's actually the second biggest city in Mexico. We love it. We spent the evening in our hostel writing blogs and watching Breaking Bad (we finally have internet fast enough to watch a show). And of course...we got more Mexican food.

item.title: San Miguel de Allende - San Miguel de Allende, Mexico
item.description: We parted from Fran for the weekend to go checkout the beautiful city of San Miguel. But we should have planned our departure better... We arrived Friday night during a Film Festival. Apparently it's the busiest weekend of the year. Finding accommodation was like finding an English speaker in Brazil. We walked around for 2 hours until we finally convinced someone outside of town to let us in for only one night at a highly inflated price. By the time we found a place and settled in it was
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded:
We parted from Fran for the weekend to go checkout the beautiful city of San Miguel. But we should have planned our departure better... We arrived Friday night during a Film Festival. Apparently it's the busiest weekend of the year. Finding accommodation was like finding an English speaker in Brazil. We walked around for 2 hours until we finally convinced someone outside of town to let us in for only one night at a highly inflated price. By the time we found a place and settled in it was midnight, and we were NOT in the mood to party. Bed. The next morning we walked around the city looking for accommodation for that evening. Nothing. So we said screw it and bought a bus ticket to Queretaro, another city about an hour and a half away. Laura has a friend there, so we were hoping to visit anyway. Our bus wasn't until that evening, so we still had a chance to see the "oh so beautiful" San Miguel. It was okay... It has a really cool church. I think we were bitter the whole day because we felt like we bussed there only to get turned around. Lots of schnazzy looking people were wandering the streets as if they were about to walk the red carpet (they're actually was a red carpet at the Film Festival). Laura and I felt... poor. So to fit in we went to a fancy hotel and bought mojitos. But they were on happy hour so I guess we didn't do that good of a job. After some more aimless wondering and picture taking, we headed back to the bus station and caught a ride to Queretaro. Good riddance San Miguel!

item.title: Mexico City - Mexico City, Mexico
item.description: Our friend Fran picked us up at the airport early in the morning after two layovers and 26 hours of travel. Mexico City is ENORMOUS! It's the third biggest in the world in terms of area, so we were never able to see the city limits. They also have giant flags all over town that I am pretty sure would completely crush numerous cars if detached from their flagpoles. Fran lives in a beautiful house with his dad, step mom, step sister, and a german shephard, "Hans". Hans gets his exercise by running
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded:
Our friend Fran picked us up at the airport early in the morning after two layovers and 26 hours of travel. Mexico City is ENORMOUS! It's the third biggest in the world in terms of area, so we were never able to see the city limits. They also have giant flags all over town that I am pretty sure would completely crush numerous cars if detached from their flagpoles. Fran lives in a beautiful house with his dad, step mom, step sister, and a german shephard, "Hans". Hans gets his exercise by running next to the car, going over 35 mph. Their home is in one of the nicest neighborhoods in Mexico City. The neighboring houses include a castle that was brought over from Germany and re-assembled, the owner of General Electric, and dozens of luxury cars. We were in an Alfa Romeo for the week. Fran also has a bodyguard who is ex-police and ex-military. He followed us around for almost all of our stay, staying an indiscreet 20-30 feet behind us. Don't mess with Fernando. After dropping our bags at his house, we all went for quesadillas and fried cow brain tacos. Surprisingly tasty. Then came the city tour of old town. We saw the Presidential Palace, a really old church that is slowly sinking (Mexico City is built on a lake), some pyramid ruins, and one of the downtown outdoor shopping streets. Included were meat and cheese tapas and delicious chocolate truffles. Fran's dad owns four (soon to be five) Italian restaurants in the city. We went to his restaurant that night and were treated to an absolutely delicious meal. Stuffed and exhausted, we went home and fell asleep at 7 PM. We didn't wake up for thirteen hours. Day two started with a trip to Xochimilco. It can best be described as a float down the river in colorful boats with mariachi bands, potato chips with hot sauce, and beer...with hot sauce (michelada). The Mexicans love to party on the boats there - even when we went at 10:00 AM. After our relaxing float we grabbed chocolate croissants and went to the swanky part of town to look at diamonds and meet Fran's mom for sushi. I even ate a plain slab of raw fish. I was very proud. Fran's Dad took us out to dinner that night. We went to a giant cafeteria with delicious tacos, horchata, and crazy Mexico juice: Jamaica. I can't stop smiling with all the delicious Mexican food here. It is long overdue. Day three welcomed us with delicious (and enormous) ham and cheese tacos. We then drove through an enormous park downtown to a real-life historical castle, Chapultepec. It is on top of a hill overlooking the whole city. Fran's great-grandpa made the cricket sculpture in the garden - turns out he was quite the artist. After getting our fill of castle, we went to a hipster market to get our fill of tacos, champagne, and Mezcal. We then went to a friend (Lulu)'s bakery for chocolate croissants, and then Fran's dads restaurant. That night we went to the mall. The next morning we get more chocolate croissants, then went to some circle pyramids in the middle of town. They were empty and beautiful. We took the afternoon to relax. Then Frans dad treated the three of us to dinner at a beautiful old hacienda called the San Angel Inn. I was shocked at how beautiful it was. One of the most beautiful restaurants I've ever been in. We ate ant eggs (which were surprisingly large), ribeye tacos, and I had one of the best margaritas of my life. The nest day Fran's mom picked us up to go to the Xochicalco pyramids an hour outside town. The complex was ENORMOUS. And supposedly only 1/10th of it has been uncovered. You could climb the pyramids, and even go inside them to see the room where the Aztecs used to monitor the sun. Then we were off to Taxco, one of Mexico's "magic cities". It is famous for silver, and it's quaint white buildings sprawl over a mountainside. We met a 13-year old tour guide who joined us for parking, lunch (he ordered a steak without hesitation), shopping, and a church tour by his brother. We passed out as soon as we got home, and were invited to Fran's mom's house for breakfast our last morning before going to the bus station. Fruit, yogurt, chocolate croissants (yet again), chilaquiles, and huevos rancheros. YUM. Our time with Fran was amazing. We felt spoiled - make that we were spoiled, and got a first-class tour of Mexico City. Excited for him to visit Colorado in December so we can repay the kindness.

item.title: Calle de Muerte - Sucre, Bolivia
item.description: We left Cochabamba late at night and arrived in familiar La Paz around 5 AM. Our previous hostel was completely booked, so we settled for one down the street. We ate breakfast, passed out, and the signed up for "Calle de Muerte" (Road of Death) the next day. Calle de Muerte is an old dirt road that used to be a major transport link between La Paz and the surrounding valley. There are many tight turns (without guard rails) next to steep cliffs. Apparently you can still see wreckage if you look
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded:
We left Cochabamba late at night and arrived in familiar La Paz around 5 AM. Our previous hostel was completely booked, so we settled for one down the street. We ate breakfast, passed out, and the signed up for "Calle de Muerte" (Road of Death) the next day. Calle de Muerte is an old dirt road that used to be a major transport link between La Paz and the surrounding valley. There are many tight turns (without guard rails) next to steep cliffs. Apparently you can still see wreckage if you look off some of the cliffs, hence the name: Death Road. We didn't see any wreckage, but we did see graves. Thankfully now there's a new, safer road that the Bolivians use leaving Death Road to be repurposed to tourists.... and downhill mountain biking. Groovy baby. We were picked up at 6am and traveled for an hour or so to the top of the valley. Here, were sized up for the proper mountain bike (Rocky Mountain Bicycle frames might I add). Then we began the high speed decent. The beginning is paved and is part of the new road that replaced Calle de Muerte. It was freezing! Laura and I were 99% sure our fingers were going to fall off. But eventually we hit the traditional dirt road which slowed things down. In addition to the lower altitude, things warmed up quick. We zigged and zagged through waterfalls and rivers, and dodged numerous cliff sides. It sounds scary, but when you're as pro as Laura and I, it ain't no thang. In total, the decent was more than 10,000 feet and took approximately two and a half hours. At the end we celebrated with a beer and ate lunch at a nice hotel. Then it was back to the city for a final meal before our flight to Mexico! Laura insisted that she get one more fresh squeezed orange juice and a bag of chocolate covered raisins before we go. I don't think we ever mentioned it, but there's fresh juice everywhere in Bolivia.

item.title: Visiting Beiba (no, not Justin Beiber) - Cochabamba, Bolivia
item.description: At 4:30AM, we rolled into Cochabamba. It is definitely more of a working city than a tourist city, thus our hostel was located more in the "suburbs". We took a taxi from the bus station in the center of the city to our hostel. When we arrived, we were stopped by concrete walls and a big black gate. Like good civilized people, we rang the doorbell and waited for an answer. Five minutes later, a man opened the door revealing a huge compound within. Green grass, trees, and hammocks. It was like
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded:
At 4:30AM, we rolled into Cochabamba. It is definitely more of a working city than a tourist city, thus our hostel was located more in the "suburbs". We took a taxi from the bus station in the center of the city to our hostel. When we arrived, we were stopped by concrete walls and a big black gate. Like good civilized people, we rang the doorbell and waited for an answer. Five minutes later, a man opened the door revealing a huge compound within. Green grass, trees, and hammocks. It was like taking a portal to another planet. But considering how early it was, we decided to hit the sack rather than mingle with nature. The next day we hit up the local supermarket and looked for a few presents for the next day (keep reading and it will make sense). Then we relaxed. And it was awesome. On Monday, we waited outside our hostel gate to be picked up by World Vision (a child sponsorship organization). I've been sponsoring a now-12-year-old girl named Beiba for years, practicing my spanish through letters with her. We figured that while in Bolivia we might as well stop by to visit her and see World Vision at work. We were just expecting to meet Beiba and to talk to the local employees about the programs and their effectiveness. So when we arrived in Colomi to a room full of staff and kids, Beiba's entire family (parents, brother, and sister), and a breakfast buffet, we were very surprised (and slightly embarassed). The kids put on a play for us, and then we made our way to some rehab facilities World Vision started in Candelaria: Beiba's town. There was a mental and physical rehabilitation center. The two have since been intentionally passed off to the Bolivian government, but are still monitored by World Vision to make sure supplies and staff needs are heard. It was encouraging to see World Vision know when to step up, and when to step down and hand over ownership and awareness to the local government. Then we made a half hour drive to Beiba's community. The tour started with lunch overlooking the lake and a fish farm. After stuffing ourselves with fish and rice, we went to the primary school in the area. Here some of the school kids took up full-sized USA and Bolivia flags and led us in a parade down a dirt road to their school. We played parachute games, watched choreographed songs and dances, and got to know eachother. Beiba started opening up, telling me about the delicious ducks on the water and reciting the dates of my birthday and wedding anniversary, which she had memorized. From there we walked to Beiba's house, which was right near the beautiful lake. Her dad owned farm land up the hill, and Beiba took great pride showing me every flower and vegetable in their home garden. Her dad had gone fishing on the lake the night before, and her mom served up the piping hot fried fish with rice and vegetables. I'm not a fish person, but this was legitimately delicious. After a pleasant meal, we passed out presents (Beiba's birthday was that coming Saturday), and said our goodbyes and thank-yous. Beiba made me a neon pink and purple scarf that took her 2 weeks. So sweet. As we were leaving we stopped on the side of the road to learn how local "chips" are made (by stomping on them and leaving them outside in the frost). These chips can be saved for years before re-hydrating and cooking. As the day ended, we headed back to the Colomi World Vision office for a birthday celebration, copious amounts of sugar, and a couple local gifts from the organization to us. I was extremely impressed by the dedication of the staff. All were local and friendly, most commuted over an hour, and all believed in the work they were doing. Our main guide for the day, Sophia, explained that there were no other children aid programs that she knew of in Bolivia, but that World Vision supports 42 villages, with emphasis on community development projects. All the kids we saw in the play earlier were part of World Vision "scouts", where kids learn about God, their rights as citizens, hygiene, and proper treatment of people. Three thousand out of eleven thousand children in Beiba's area are sponsored. Throughout our travels I have become wary of locals seeing the west as the "white rich people" with bottomless pockets and all the answers. I see local leadership and empowerment from within the community as healthier and more effective means of development. But there is also something to be said for giving kids a kick-start in life and letting them know someone across the world believes in them. No system is perfect, but Mark and I believe World Vision uses their money well and wholeheartedly. The next day we went to the Jesus statue of Cochabamba, which is bigger than the one in Rio. Also less crowded and more pleasant. Later we (finally) finished our tourist shopping in town. That night and the next day were spent at our hostel chatting with a German girl and a British couple (who just became great-grandparents) that have been traveling for 10 years. That's right. 10 YEARS. I can't even imagine.

item.title: Sucre...For Real This Time - Sucre, Bolivia
item.description: Back in the relative warmth in Sucre, we decided to relax for three days. But Mark and I are terrible at relaxing. This whole trip we haven't stayed anywhere for more than a week. Our three days were filled with blogging, doing overdue chores, buying airline tickets for Mexico, and bus tickets our next stop, Cochabamba. We don't really feel relaxed, but it was still nice to be in one place for more than a day or two. The city is beautiful. Also, our terrace rooftop hostel included a kitchen,
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Back in the relative warmth in Sucre, we decided to relax for three days. But Mark and I are terrible at relaxing. This whole trip we haven't stayed anywhere for more than a week. Our three days were filled with blogging, doing overdue chores, buying airline tickets for Mexico, and bus tickets our next stop, Cochabamba. We don't really feel relaxed, but it was still nice to be in one place for more than a day or two. The city is beautiful. Also, our terrace rooftop hostel included a kitchen, cable TV (almost exclusively in Spanish), and wifi. Great place to hunker down before our next move to Cochabamba! Sorry no pictures. This was "relaxing" time.

item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: After a bus, taxi, and another bus, we arrived in freezing Uyuni (literally, below 32 degrees) just after 1 AM. We wandered the ghost town until we found an open hotel with a triple room. Done. Our tour started at 10 AM the next morning. We ate breakfast and stuffed ourselves into the Toyota 4Runner that would be our home for the next three days. We shared the car with our guide, Marine, two Danish guys, and two Swiss guys. Sitting in the middle of the car, surrounded by big men, I felt very safe. It's hard to describe how pretty the landscape was. I'll try, but recommend seeing the photos to get a better idea of our tour. The first day included a visit to the train graveyard, a dust field full of trains from waaaay back in the day, and the famous Salina de Uyuni, an ancient ocean that dried up and left behind TONS of salt on a giant flat plain. In the middle, rising up from all the flat salt, was Cactus Island - a green oasis of cactus. Really cool. That night we stayed in a small salt hotel. Literally, it was made of salt. The outside was...underwhelming, but the inside beautiful. Unfortunately a couple of German girls and English guys didn't realize sound travels through salt. And there were some rowdy Israelis who hot-boxed the place with cigarettes. We were happy to leave the next day. Day 2 was lagoon day. We saw four lakes of "different colors". They weren't necessarily vibrant rainbow colors, but they sure were really nice to look at. We also saw amazing mountains, volcanos, the border of Chile, flamingos, a rock that looks like a big tree, and lots of llamas. Our next hotel was really cold and simple, but offered yogurt, cereal, AND pancakes for breakfast. Oh, yumm! The last day featured fast driving (to the point of super scary), geysers, natural hot springs, a green lagoon, and a flat tire. It was SO cold that we were using our sleeping bag as a blanket in the car (the cars heater was broken). Seven hour of driving later, we made it to peaceful Uyuni in time to watch Brazil get destroyed by Germany 7-1 in the World Cup. We bought a bus ticket for the next day and checked into the same hotel for a lukewarm shower and some much-needed sleep.

item.title: Sucre - Sucre, Bolivia
item.description: After a night of sleep on the bus we popped into Sucre. A super relaxing (and warm) town that used to Bolivia's capital. We grabbed a taxi with our new Polish friends and ended up and some mom and pop hostel that looked pretty nice. But little did we know the horrors to come... We settled in, took a shower and went out to watch a FIFA game. After the game, we went back to our hostel to take a nap as it was the 4th of July and we had plans to bon fire later that evening with another American we
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: After a night of sleep on the bus we popped into Sucre. A super relaxing (and warm) town that used to Bolivia's capital. We grabbed a taxi with our new Polish friends and ended up and some mom and pop hostel that looked pretty nice. But little did we know the horrors to come... We settled in, took a shower and went out to watch a FIFA game. After the game, we went back to our hostel to take a nap as it was the 4th of July and we had plans to bon fire later that evening with another American we met. An hour or so went by and then I woke up scratching. You guessed it! BED BUGS AGIAN! That makes our 7th encounter with the devils in under a year. Immediately, we went through our cleaning drill and switched rooms. So much for the 4th. The bugs took the party out of us. The next day we decided to completely move hostels because the staff was giving us a hard time about the bugs (and didn't believe us). Then we cruised around town, visited a ginormous cemetery, and checked out tours to Uyuni: the popular tourist thing to do in Bolivia (see next post). However, their have been lots of blockades recently making it a tough place to get to. Most places said we wouldn't be able to go for weeks. But then one lady told us we could go, but we would have to go now (before the blockades started again). STRESS TIME! Cancel our hostel booking, pack our bags, buy the last two seats on a bus to Potosi, and catch a late night bus to Uyuni from there. It's times like these that we are grateful that we only have one backpack to pack and carry :-)

item.title: Copacabana, Isla del Sol - Isla del Sol , Bolivia
item.description: The journey to Copacabana included a bus ride, a ferry, and another bus ride. We arrived in Copacabana and found ourselves in a beautiful hotel room on the edge of Lake Titicaca. Absolutely beautiful. We found a bar to watch the USA game (with a room full of Belgians and Bolivians), and were disappointed by the result (Belgium won). Luckily the loss was padded by friendly Belgian trash talk, and a pity drink from the Bolivians. The next morning we took a ferry to Isla del Sol. The "thing to do"
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: The journey to Copacabana included a bus ride, a ferry, and another bus ride. We arrived in Copacabana and found ourselves in a beautiful hotel room on the edge of Lake Titicaca. Absolutely beautiful. We found a bar to watch the USA game (with a room full of Belgians and Bolivians), and were disappointed by the result (Belgium won). Luckily the loss was padded by friendly Belgian trash talk, and a pity drink from the Bolivians. The next morning we took a ferry to Isla del Sol. The "thing to do" is hike the island from North to South. The views are incredible, the stone ruins cool, the water crystal clear, and the sun scorching. Thankfully we were forewarned and came prepared with sunglasses and sunscreen. We met a friendly Germany guy who shared a pizza with us at a restaurant with an absolutely unbelievable location overlooking the water. His ear was black and bloody, having been bitten by a monkey at the monkey sanctuary he was staying at. This further justifies my fear of monkeys. Safely arriving at the South end of the island three hours later, we checked into a hostel, sharing a room with a nice French couple. We spent the evening walking to the water (which meant a giant climb uphill to our place), and chatting with a hippy Polish couple, who would prove to be recurring friends on our trip. The next day was a big travel day. 2 hour ferry, then a 3 hour bus to La Paz, then an overnight bus to Sucre (we wanted to go to Uyuni, but the road was closed due to strikes - the people want a bus terminal). Exhausted, we shared a taxi in Sucre with our new Polish friends and counted in our heads the number of bus rides left in our future.

item.title: La Paz - La Paz, Bolivia

Unfortunately we were made to go through immigration in Cochabamba (during our layover). They asked for the money, a copy of our credit card, our flight out of the country, hostel reservation, invitation into Bolivia, and also our vaccination records. This was the second
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We had done some quick research on Bolivian immigration. Every blog said America is one of the only countries that has to pay, and if you are flying into La Paz you need to bring the fee in US dollars and they will let you in. Unfortunately we were made to go through immigration in Cochabamba (during our layover). They asked for the money, a copy of our credit card, our flight out of the country, hostel reservation, invitation into Bolivia, and also our vaccination records. This was the second worst immigration experience we've ever had (after India). Thankfully an airport worker had us e-mail her the information over the snail-slow internet, and printed the pages. The immigration man didn't even look at the papers, just found our name on each page and let us through. As a result, we missed our original fight but thankfully we were able to catch the last flight of the night to La Paz! We arrived in La Paz and took a shared taxi with a friendly local archaeologist and another local (airport taxis are all shared). The city is built in a valley with crazy hills soaring up on the sides. Everything you can see is covered in earth-colored buildings. It's really, REALLY big. We made our way to our hostel, settled in, and conked out. The internet at our original hostel didn't work, so the next morning we changed places and walked around town until our 4:30 PM main event of the day: Cholitas Wrestling! "Cholitas" is the correct name for the indigenous women who live in Bolivia. They all wear poofy skirts (to look bigger), sweaters, and tiny bowler hats. Cholitas wrestling is basically WWF (fake fighting), but with middle-aged men in spandex costumes and Cholitas women fighters. The event takes place in neighboring El Alto, on top of the La Paz hill, in a tiny gym with a fighting ring. The audience is half Bolivian, half tourist. Highlights included the audience throwing popcorn and water at the "bad guys'", a wrestler being thrown onto three tourists in the audience, and a man back-flipping from the top of the ring onto his opponent on the cement below. We were laughing really hard. See the below photos for some visuals. After all the excitement, we found some street burgers to enjoy with the free nightly beer from our hostel and an over-due game of fooseball. The next morning we enjoyed the other perk of our new hostel: an all you can eat pancake breakfast! After stuffing ourselves, we walked to the main plaza for a free city walking tour. We had it in our heads that walking tours are generally lame, but (besides the crazy NY man who tries to get tips for information about the jail he just got out of), this tour was awesome. The two women leading it were hilarious and full of fun facts. We learned why the local women wear tiny bowler hats: years ago the men in Bolivia ordered bowler hats from Europe. Europe figured their heads would be tiny since the men are short. When the tiny hats arrived the men tricked the women into buying them as the "newest feminine fashion in Europe". They're up to $750 each and still bought and worn today. You can tell if a woman is single or taken by how she wears the hat. The women here also wear layers and layers of skirts to look bigger. They do all the work, and men find the bigger women more attractive. To seduce the men, they lift their skirts to show their calves. On the tour we also learned about a witch street that sells llama fetuses. Whenever a new building is made a fetus is purchased to bring good luck on the structure. A couple generations ago when really big buildings were being created, a witch doctor would be hired to send his men to find a homeless person that would not be missed. They would then give him booze until he passed out, and bury him alive in the foundation of the new structure. Thankfully this no longer happens, but bodies are occasionally found when tearing down old buildings. OK sorry - enough of random facts...you can go on the tour or talk to us for more. The next morning we boarded another bus - this one bound for Copacabana (a different Copacabana from Brazil) and the Isla Del Sol.

item.title: São Paulo - São Paulo, Brazil
item.description: We rolled into Sao Paolo at 7 AM on an overnight bus from Rio. It is really big. As in one of the biggest cities in the world. After a few subways during rush hour and a walk through some quirky street art, we reached Pat's apartment in the Vila Madalena neighborhood. Pat is a generous soul who volunteered to host us for a few nights. We know his brother, Ricardo, from Colorado. He is a brother in the Catholic Church who helps to organize volunteer trips to South America. I've done one trip, and
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We rolled into Sao Paolo at 7 AM on an overnight bus from Rio. It is really big. As in one of the biggest cities in the world. After a few subways during rush hour and a walk through some quirky street art, we reached Pat's apartment in the Vila Madalena neighborhood. Pat is a generous soul who volunteered to host us for a few nights. We know his brother, Ricardo, from Colorado. He is a brother in the Catholic Church who helps to organize volunteer trips to South America. I've done one trip, and Mark has done two. We found the key under his mat, opened the door, and our jaws dropped. It was beautiful. His bachelor apartment was big, clean, chic, and had an amazing view of the city. We took a shower, found our bed (in our private room), and fell asleep until 2:00 PM. We got up the energy to go to a crazy coffee place in his neighborhood. You can choose your coffee from an enormous list, choose how you want it brewed, and they bring all the supplies to your table to brew in front of you. Crazy. Back at the house, we met Pat and had some wine on the porch. His parents had invited the three of us to their place for dinner, so that was our next stop. Pat's parents live walking distance away in a breathtaking apartment building. From their apartment (which is a whole floor) you can see far into the distance. Sao Paolo is so big that all you could see was city with no end. His mom prepared us delicious seafood curry and a delicious passion fruit/condensed milk/gelatin desert that I want to try my hand at when we get home. Pat's dad, American, told us all about their lives and travels. The next morning our friend Kate, who we went to Peru with five years ago, picked us up to explore. She is an artist who has been living outside the city for three months, and teaches english in Sao Paolo a few times a week. We first went to the USA vs. Germany game at a packed bar down the street. America lost, but still made it to the next round! After the game we went to grab street hamburgers and walk to an art exhibition. This extremely famous Japanese woman who lives in an asylum and is obsessed with polka-dots was offering a free look at her latest art, which was...unique. We enjoyed it. That night I made a prochutto/squash/spinach/gnochi dish that was absolutely delicious. Score one for me! Afterward our tired caught up to us again - we watched a new movie about a true story of US special forces in Afghanistan. It was excellent but a little intense for me. So we watched Mythbusters afterward. Our last day in Sao Paolo started with lunch out with Pat in the business district. Then we walked around and received an official tour of the area (including a chaotic market) with Kate and him. Mark made delicious chicken with beans and rice for dinner, and then it was time to party. Pat had turned 30 the week before while on vacation, so he decided to throw a big party to celebrate. It was a grown-up party, complete with food and a full bar. We bought crazy chestnut-like things to roast as a snack that were surprisingly delicious. We were awake until everyone left at 4 AM (people stay up late in Brazil), and got up at 7 AM to make our way to the airport before the city went to a standstill for the Brazil soccer game.

item.title: Rio - Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
item.description: We were picked up in Rio by our Airbnb host, Jefferson. I can't remember if we've talked about Airbnb. It's basically Couchsurfing, but you pay for it. Showing up in Rio during the World Cup (where one dorm bed in a hostel is $90/night/pp) made us look for alternative lodging options. We shared Jefferson and his wife's (Nina) bedroom along with their dog (Scott) and two cats (Cheetah and John). A little tight, but they were super nice, showed us the city, and we got a good price downtown.
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: We were picked up in Rio by our Airbnb host, Jefferson. I can't remember if we've talked about Airbnb. It's basically Couchsurfing, but you pay for it. Showing up in Rio during the World Cup (where one dorm bed in a hostel is $90/night/pp) made us look for alternative lodging options. We shared Jefferson and his wife's (Nina) bedroom along with their dog (Scott) and two cats (Cheetah and John). A little tight, but they were super nice, showed us the city, and we got a good price downtown. Shortly after we arrived, Jefferson and Nina took us to an all you can eat pizza joint with a few of their friends. I think it was the first time we've seen "All You Can Eat" since we left the states. We stuffed our faces, even though the pizza was more like cheese bread. Most restaurants in Brazil are a buffet and charge you by weight. We didn't realize this when we first arrived from Argentina, and definitely paid a hefty price at our first bus rest stop. Most of their friends are into Muay Thai, and were trying to get me to come train. I told them maybe... The area we were in is called Lapa, which is where most of the night life happens. At night, the streets become so full of people that the police often have to close the roads so nobody gets run over. Street stands get up all over the place selling greasy hotdogs (with raisins), and of course a wide selection of alcoholic beverages. There are no open container tickets, so the entire district of Lapa basically becomes a giant bar/urinal/grease stand. Surprisingly it's actually pretty fun to walk through. Musicians play samba in the streets, often battling each other like a drumline. On our second night a friend from grad-school, Porter, met us. He was also touring Brazil with a couple of his friends. While we were eating, a bunch of people protesting FIFA came marching down the street. Some of the Brazilians are against hosting the World Cup because they think the money could have been better spent elsewhere (which is probably true). Either way, they came marching down the streets with their signs saying F*** FIFA. Right behind them was an excessively large police force (including a helicopter) making sure everything stayed peaceful. We're not sure things remained peaceful because we definitely caught whiffs of tear gas while we were finishing our meal. The next day Jefferson took us on a tour around the city. We saw some of the major government buildings, and one of the craziest churches we've ever seen. The entire thing is built out of concrete. Laura thinks it's ugly. I think it's pretty cool looking. At night, we went to see Jefferson's friend from England, Deepak, rap at a local hostal bar. Yes, Deepak is his real name. Not his rapper name. He can drop the beats! In an English accent even... The following day Laura and I checked out Sugarloaf: a "mountain" that overlooks the city of Rio from the ocean. Most people take a gondola to the top but Jefferson told us that you can hike half way up, so we opted for the hike to build character. He accompanied us along the slippery trail which took out quite a few tourists. But it was all worth it when we saw the views at the top. You can see the ocean and Rio with the Christ the Redeemer statue looking over the city. Pretty epic. After Sugarloaf we went straight to Copacabana beach for "FIFA Fun Fest" where they would play the USA - Portugal game. FIFA Fun Fest is basically a giant party on the beach with a huge TV to watch the games. Porter and his friends met us and brought some extra USA face paint for us to sport. The US had officially taken over the beach, outnumbering Portuguese fans 10:1. All of you should know the result of the game (the US was up 2-1, but Portugal scored in the last minute to tie). By the end of the game, I lost my voice and the beach was quiet. We were in shock. Still had a great time, especially talking smack to the Portugese, and booing Ronaldo every time he was on TV. Hotdogs were waiting for us back at the apartment. The next day we opted for another hike. This time to the Christ the Redeemer statue that overlooks Rio. The trail starts in a botanical gardens and works its way through the forest up to the mountain where the statue stands. It's absolutely gorgeous, but STEEP. At one point we were literally rock climbing, holding on to a chain that was bolted into the rock. Underneath us were Brazilian police watching us. Probably ready to take tourists to the hospital if they fell. Once we finally made it to the top, we were turned around because we were told we had to buy tickets down below (the opposite of what was posted on their website). Buzz kill! So after 2 hours of a grueling hike, we had to take a bus back down to buy a ticket and then bus back up. Lame. The statue was also packed with tourists from the World Cup. You could barely lift up your hands to take a picture. But just like the Sugarloaf hike, it was worth it in the end. The statue is huge and the views of the city are superb. While we were there a guy was working on Jesus' finger. Apparently it got hit by lightning. After hiking back down, we were able to catch the second half of the Brazil - Mexico game at our hosts apartment. They had popcorn and juice waiting for us. We devoured the snacks as we had eaten nothing after the hike. Deepak was also there and suggested we go out for "all you can eat" pizza again. Laura and I quickly agreed. 20 cheesy pizza slices and a stomach ache later, we hit the sack. Exhausted. Our last day in Rio was a beach day. Ipanima beach and Copacabana. Tourists and locals alike litter these giant beaches playing soccer, drinking beer, and soaking up the sun. We rented bikes and cruised around the city people watching. The whole world has packed itself onto these beaches for the World Cup, so you definitely stay entertained. As the sun went down we biked home to catch a city bus to the regional bus station where we would catch a ride to São Paulo. We bid farewell to our awesome Airbnb hosts and caught a bus to the bus station. By the way, the bus drivers in Rio are absolutely nuts. If you've ever seen the movie: SPEED, that's what it felt like. I'm pretty sure we took a few u-turns at 30+ mph. Not kidding.

item.title: Ouro Preto: "Gold Black" - Ouro Preto, Brazil
item.description: We were met at the Ouro Preto bus station by Breno and his friend Paul. We would be couch surfing at their fraternity for the night. "Fraternity" conjures images of keg parties and a trashed house, but in Ouro Preto they are more of a big house for friends to live together. We were greeted by friendly roommates, and our own bed. Awesome. Thankfully everyone in Breno's house spoke Spanish or English, so we got by fine. Breno showed us the local university, and also took us for a walk through the
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We were met at the Ouro Preto bus station by Breno and his friend Paul. We would be couch surfing at their fraternity for the night. "Fraternity" conjures images of keg parties and a trashed house, but in Ouro Preto they are more of a big house for friends to live together. We were greeted by friendly roommates, and our own bed. Awesome. Thankfully everyone in Breno's house spoke Spanish or English, so we got by fine. Breno showed us the local university, and also took us for a walk through the beautiful old downtown. We visited a church with an inside completely covered in gold - the second most "golded" church in Brazil. The hills covered in beautiful buildings made us feel like we were in a mini-utopia. Toward the end of our walk we were stopped by three middle-aged women in the town square. They had had a few beers, and asked to take a photo with us. They then proceeded to tell us how beautiful we are and how cute our accents are. They gave us their phone numbers and invited us to stay with them and their families an hour outside the city. Breno couldn't stop laughing. That night we made shokshooka (an Israeli egg dish) for the house, and Breno made us his famous caparinas (a Brazilian drink similar to a margarita). A couple of his roommates had studied english but never had the opportunity to speak to native english speakers. They really enjoyed telling us stories and practicing. It was a lot of fun hanging out on their back porch overlooking the city. We took the local city bus to the bus station the next morning to catch our ride to Rio. Unfortunately a few minutes into the ride we were stopped due to a parade. It turns out that these celebrations happen often. After waiting 15 minutes we decided to ditch the bus and go to the station on foot so we wouldn't miss our bus. Unfortunately this meant a mile-long run up big cobblestone hills filled with celebration preparations. Not ideal. We made it minutes before the bus left, purchasing the last two tickets.

item.title: Belo Horizonte - Belo Horizonte, Brazil
item.description: What do you get when you put an engineer, a lawyer, and a traveling married couple in a 3-bedroom apartment? Our time in Belo Horizonte! We arrived at Belo Horizonte at 9 PM after a wonderful (sarcasm) 31-hour bus ride. We asked the woman working information at the bus station if she could talk in spanish or english...the answer was "no". Turns out most Brazilians only speak portugese - the biggest language-barrier country we have found so far. We walked out of the station toward the subway,
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: What do you get when you put an engineer, a lawyer, and a traveling married couple in a 3-bedroom apartment? Our time in Belo Horizonte! We arrived at Belo Horizonte at 9 PM after a wonderful (sarcasm) 31-hour bus ride. We asked the woman working information at the bus station if she could talk in spanish or english...the answer was "no". Turns out most Brazilians only speak portugese - the biggest language-barrier country we have found so far. We walked out of the station toward the subway, quickly finding ourselves surrounded by transvestites, hourly hotels, and drunk people. Exhausted and sketched out, we gave in and got a taxi. The driver didn't speak English but was extremely nice; he even caught our overpayment mistake. We booked and Airbnb reservation (like Couch Surfing, but you pay) to stay with Mateus and his roommate Sergio near the university. Mateus only spoke Portugese (a rediculous mix of Spanish, French and Italian with a twist of Russian accent), but Sergio is fluent in English, which was excellent. We could communicate with Mateus by speaking Spanish, but the translation of Portugese back to Spanish could be a little rough. Thankfully they turned out to be amazingly friendly hosts with an apartment in a wonderful location. Sergio's sister was visiting the first night, so we all walked to "FIFA Fan Fest", which has screenings of the soccer games, nightly live bands, an indoor amusement park ride, and plenty of scantily-clad Brazilians. We were in absolute shock after all the modest countries on our travels. I hadn't seen so much thigh since we were in the states. Then we ate delicious burritos. Day two we picked up our World Cup game tickets at a big mall downtown. This was perfect, because after having my bag stolen I was in need of clothes. Big time. Shopping successful, tickets in hand, we prepped for the big USA vs Ghana game. We met one of Sergio's friends at a bar downtown, and soon found a whole smattering of eager Americans glued to numerous TVs. WE WON!! Now I can't say that I watch any soccer, but I am extremely competitive, and something about the World Cup is consuming. I am completely into it. After the successful game we drove with Sergio to pick up "Cha Cha", a 90 year old Indian/English/Brazilian man who is volunteering for the World Cup. He owns a store where Sergio went to university, and stays on Sergio's couch whenever he is in town for a night. The four of us drank chai tea, looked through Cha Cha's photo albums, and learned simple stretching and movement exercises that keep Cha Cha "feeling young". Excellent man. By the time we waited in crazy traffic, hiked 1 mile from where the bus dropped us off, ran in a complete circle around the stadium, and finally found our seats, the Algeria - Belgium game was underway. It was absolutely amazing to be so close to the players, especially because they all look so tiny on TV. The team we finally decided as our favorite (Belgium) won, so we left celebrating. About half the people at the game were Brazilian. In the celebration one proposed his love to me, and another kissed my hand (under Mark's careful watch). Brazil played that night, so we went directly from the game to Sergio's friends' house to watch Brazil and fill up on delicious BBQ and homemade limeade. The celebration continued at Fifa Fan Fest, with live Samba music, dancing, and excellent people watching. The next morning Mateus drove us to the bus station to begin our journey southward.

item.description: We left Tilcara at 11am for... you guessed it... another bus ride! Little did we know that we wouldn't get to our destination, Iguazu Falls for 33 hours. Turns out we had to make four extra bus transfers than we wanted to, and when we finally got on our last bus, we were greeted with the knowledge that we would be going on a 7 hour detour. Turns out the Iguazu are had some serious flooding and the main road in and out was closed. But we could go around! IIt wasn't all bad. We used the time to
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: We left Tilcara at 11am for... you guessed it... another bus ride! Little did we know that we wouldn't get to our destination, Iguazu Falls for 33 hours. Turns out we had to make four extra bus transfers than we wanted to, and when we finally got on our last bus, we were greeted with the knowledge that we would be going on a 7 hour detour. Turns out the Iguazu are had some serious flooding and the main road in and out was closed. But we could go around! IIt wasn't all bad. We used the time to make two new friends from Seattle: Seth and Tana. They have been touring all of South America by car and recently sold it, leaving them hostage to the same bus ride as us. Finally we arrived at in Iguazu at 8pm the day after leaving Tilcara. Seth and Tana had hostel reservations, and we were exhausted so we just latched on to them hoping we would get accommodation as well. Luckily the lady at the front desk told us that we could share a family size room. On the bus ride we had been telling them about our bed bug horror stories, so Seth sarcastically ripped off the covers of their bed to make sure they never suffer the same fate as us. Then he says, "Mark, is this mold?" I come over and take a look, "BED BUGS!!!!!" Not again! That makes 6 encounters with the (insert your choice of words here) for Laura and I in under a year. We quickly ran out of the hostel (luckily we hadn't paid yet), and went searching the streets for a place to sleep. Eventually we found a nice place where we could share a room. We cooked up some grub, swapped some more stories and hit the sack. The next morning we woke up early to check out one of the wonders of the new world: Iguazu Falls. Sorry Niagra, but this sight puts you to shame. Look at the pictures. The water was extra strong, brown from the mud, and part of the falls were closed due to the flooding. But we decided we liked being able to go during the flood because not many people get to see Iguazu that "roaring". After the falls we parted ways with Seth and Tana as they were catching a flight to Natal, Brazil to watch the USA play in the World Cup. We decided to take a bus to Brazil instead. This wasn't the best decision. We just signed ourselves up for another 31 hour bus ride. 64 hours of bussing over 4 days....

After following a Colombian and Dutch guy to a hostel, we dropped off our things and explored town. It is small, full of dogs wearing felt blanket jackets, scattered with women in big hats, and very relaxed. The local culture is still well alive - and tourists are comparatively very few.
