item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: After our hike around Purmamarca, we took the next bus north and settled down in Tilcara. We were exhausted. After following a Colombian and Dutch guy to a hostel, we dropped off our things and explored town. It is small, full of dogs wearing felt blanket jackets, scattered with women in big hats, and very relaxed. The local culture is still well alive - and tourists are comparatively very few. I had a bad cold, so went to bed early. Mark woke me up around midnight. He had seen our archenemy: a bedbug. Our fifth time with these unwanted visitors, we knew the drill: catch one, change rooms, shake out our clothes, and take another shower. Itchy and no fun. The next day I summoned my energy to make the uphill hike to Garganta de Dios (The Devil's Throat) Waterfall. It was an epically beautiful hike through desert, cacti, and crazy rock formations. After a couple hours we reached the downhill climb into a canyon. We hiked up the side of a very tiny river to the waterfall. Nice, but the hike to it was better. There we met our friend, "Sam". Sam is a dog, and we shared our crackers with him. Mark fell in love. It turns out he, and other dogs in the area, follow hikers to and from town day in and day out. We had three friends join us for the hike back. At night we went to a restaurant on the plaza with delicious food and live folklore music. We tried llama for the first time, and ended our meal with a dulce de leche pancake. Absolutely delicious. The live entertainment was a middle-aged man with his guitar and the voice of an Argentinian folklore angel. We were hooked.

item.title: Purmamarca - Purmamarca, Argentina
item.description: On our way north we decided to get off the bus for a pit-stop in Pulmamarca. Our afternoon there was filled with the camino de los colorados, a hike through the desert showcasing the vibrant rock colors that the town is so famous for. There were hills covered in up to seven different kinds of rocks and colors - green, brown, red, yellow... After all the walking I stopped at a street BBQ vendor for the best empanada ever - full of ham and cheesy goodness. It was absolutely delicious. And enormous
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: On our way north we decided to get off the bus for a pit-stop in Pulmamarca. Our afternoon there was filled with the camino de los colorados, a hike through the desert showcasing the vibrant rock colors that the town is so famous for. There were hills covered in up to seven different kinds of rocks and colors - green, brown, red, yellow... After all the walking I stopped at a street BBQ vendor for the best empanada ever - full of ham and cheesy goodness. It was absolutely delicious. And enormous - bigger than my hand!

item.title: Salta - Salta, Argentina
item.description: Even though it was another 24 hour bus ride, Salta was the perfect breath of fresh air after a rough last day in Buenos Aires. The large - but slow - town was just what the doctor ordered. It had large parks, a beautiful pink cathedral, a lively central plaza, and streets full of shops. Unfortunately I couldn't find one shirt I liked in all the stores, so I spent most of the time wearing clothes from Mark's bag. Our lack of excitement for the local wear was due to the plastering of cheesy
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Even though it was another 24 hour bus ride, Salta was the perfect breath of fresh air after a rough last day in Buenos Aires. The large - but slow - town was just what the doctor ordered. It had large parks, a beautiful pink cathedral, a lively central plaza, and streets full of shops. Unfortunately I couldn't find one shirt I liked in all the stores, so I spent most of the time wearing clothes from Mark's bag. Our lack of excitement for the local wear was due to the plastering of cheesy english sayings ("you + me = happy") and plethora of turtle necks. Looks like re-stocking my clothes may be harder than expected!

item.title: City of Blood Sausage, Mate & a Stolen Backpack - Buenos Aires, Argentina
item.description: After our ridiculous flight path from South Africa -> Dubai -> Rio (lots of time for movie watching), we arrived in Buenos Aires, AKA the Europe of South America (think a shnazzy, expensive European city). Thankfully our good friend Carole connected us with her friend, Juan, who lives about 45 minutes outside downtown. After our first night in a hostel, Juan came to pick us up after work. He is our age, and lives with his sister (Agustina), and parents in a beautiful suburb of Buenos Aires.
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: After our ridiculous flight path from South Africa -> Dubai -> Rio (lots of time for movie watching), we arrived in Buenos Aires, AKA the Europe of South America (think a shnazzy, expensive European city). Thankfully our good friend Carole connected us with her friend, Juan, who lives about 45 minutes outside downtown. After our first night in a hostel, Juan came to pick us up after work. He is our age, and lives with his sister (Agustina), and parents in a beautiful suburb of Buenos Aires. Their parents were on a Jamaican beach vacation, so it was just the four of us, Mango the dog, and the house help. We were greeted our first night by a delicious traditional dinner of milanesa (breaded and baked meat) and potatoes. The whole family came over - Juan, Augstina, her boyfriend, another sister, her husband, and their new daughter. It was delicious and a whole lot of fun. Breakfast was bread, dulce de leche (thick, creamy, melty, gooey caramel), and coffee. Turns out Argentinians are very similar to Spaniards - both speak crazy castellano spanish, have a five hour siesta in the middle of the day, eat dinky breakfasts, lunch at 2, snack at 6, and dinner at 10. That schedule definitely takes some getting used to. After eating, Agustina and her good friend Belen took us on a tour of the area. We saw the local cathedral, their country club and boat (Juan and his dad love sailing), and a nearby quirky river town (El Tigre). There we were given our first traditional Mate session. Mate is the local drink - highly caffeinated leaves mixed with small doses of hot water, drank with a special anti-clog straw, and passed in a circle. Our opinion went from bitterly overwhelming to mostly enjoyable. That night Juan invited his three travel friends over for a legitimate Argentinian BBQ. He cooked blood sausages (literally made of chunks of blood), regular sausages, and a huge slab of lomo meat. I tried a few times, but couldn't get past the fact that the blood sausages were literally-simply-blood. Mark loved them. I'm wondering if he is a vampire...? The next morning Juan dropped us at the Brazilian consulate on the way to work. Finally having all the required paperwork for a World Cup visa (bank statements, flight information, photos, application forms, hostel information...), we were set free to explore downtown Buenos Aires. We walked miles and miles, ending at the famous colorful buildings of "El Caminito." We learned that almost no Argentinians dance salsa anymore, but the dance is kept alive for tourists in this area. It was really cool to watch - even if it is no longer a common cultural thing. After saying our goodbyes on Friday, we took the train into the city. We picked up our shiny new Brazilian visas, talked to a guy from New York for awhile, and went into Subway for a sandwich. That was our mistake. I was watching our big bags in the corner while Mark went to order. There was a problem with the receipt (food was double what it should have been), so we traded places so I could figure out what was wrong (I speak better Spanish). Mark was grabbing our drinks, eye on the bags, when I told him that they charged us for double meat and didn't give us the daily deal price. He said "I didn't order double meat". I looked past him and immediately noticed that my bag was gone. I sprinted out the door and down the street, Mark going the other way, but the robber was gone. Seconds. I chatted with a cop (flashback to when we get held at knifepoint in Spain a few years ago), and made a police report. We are never going to Subway again: food poisoning 2009, terrible sandwich in Africa, now this - 3 strikes, never again! Thankfully we keep all our valuables on our bodies, so all that was in my bag was clothing. While I'm sad to lose some things picked up on the road, I know the robber will be disappointed with all the dirty underwear and lack of electronics/passport/value. Cheers to lighter travel!

item.title: Brie'n up in Joburg - Johannesburg, South Africa
item.description: After our long bus adventure back to Joburg we were picked up by our new S. African friends (Quintin and Lorette) that we met in Uganda while rafting the Nile. They took us straight to their friends house in Pretoria because they were having themselves a Briie (Afrikaans for BBQ). After an hour drive we ended up in a swanky, gated community with palm trees. And their friends turned out to be an up-and-coming Afrikaans girl band, "Saarkie." We had ourselves a great time, eating local meat, having
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: After our long bus adventure back to Joburg we were picked up by our new S. African friends (Quintin and Lorette) that we met in Uganda while rafting the Nile. They took us straight to their friends house in Pretoria because they were having themselves a Briie (Afrikaans for BBQ). After an hour drive we ended up in a swanky, gated community with palm trees. And their friends turned out to be an up-and-coming Afrikaans girl band, "Saarkie." We had ourselves a great time, eating local meat, having some drinks, and chillin' with hipster crew of SA. Later that evening they took us out to a ranch sorta place for an Afrikaburn-themed birthday party. Think really small/laid back Burning Man. They burned a wooden cat sculpture. I burned a bale of hay. The next day Quintin and Lorette dropped us off at the metro and we parted ways. Laura and I had some time to kill, so we went and checked out the Nelson Mandela Plaza. Basically a big shopping mall with a big statue of Nelson. We found a Cinnabon. Life is good.

item.title: Cape Town - Cape Town, South Africa
item.description: We had talked to a few locals in Cape Town through the website couchsurfing.org (CS) prior to arriving. The website connects travelers interested in a 'local experience' with locals willing to open up their homes, interested in learning about other cultures and making friends from around the world. You are able to read all reviews about the people - good and bad - and also talk to them before agreeing to stay together. There is also a certification process. And don't worry - someone always knew
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We had talked to a few locals in Cape Town through the website couchsurfing.org (CS) prior to arriving. The website connects travelers interested in a 'local experience' with locals willing to open up their homes, interested in learning about other cultures and making friends from around the world. You are able to read all reviews about the people - good and bad - and also talk to them before agreeing to stay together. There is also a certification process. And don't worry - someone always knew where we were for safety. We got off the 20-hour bus ride from Johannesburg and got on another bus that took us 30 minutes from Cape Town to beautiful Hout Bay and the home of Maarten (2 minutes from the beach). He has hosted dozens upon dozens of people, loves to travel, and also does home exchanges and rents his three places out to vacation-goers. He is a wealth of knowledge on the area. The night we arrived we all walked down to the harbor to see the overweight seals, and then to dinner at a delicious restaurant near the beach. The next day Maarten dropped Mark and I off at the base of Table Mountain. We hiked up and down the giant geological table, stopping for a long lunch on top (there is also a cable car, but we thought we could use the exercise). Maarten was at a work meeting, so Mark and I stocked up to make ultimate salads (yes, salads - turns out we miss them) at the grocery store, and caught up on some chores we had been avoiding. Maarten took Friday off to bring us to Cape Horn. On the way we stopped at South Africa's oldest winery, Bolder's Beach (home of a bunch of endangered, funny looking penguins), a gem factory, and a beach for a picnic. Cape Horn was windy as all get-out, but absolutely spectacular. It's famous for being the southernmost tip of Africa, but is really second or third in line. I have a feeling the country just decided to label it as furthest south for tourism. It was crazy to see where two oceans come together (Indian and Atlantic). We also visited another nearby point, the Cape of Good Hope. On the way back home we stopped by an ostrich farm for some coffee, and to have our hands pecked at by impressively strong beaks. After a 30 cent McDonalds ice cream and a beautiful sunset in a schnazzy neighborhood, we went to a crazy indoor market that is only on Fridays. It takes place in an old warehouse by the ocean. They decorate the whole thing, bring in vendors, delicious food, and livebands. It is absolutely beautiful, and hipster-tastic. The next day we were passed off to another CS host, Ofer (and his two mini greyhound dogs: Romeo and Fabio). He lives in Table View, on the opposite side of Cape Town. Our first night we all went out to dinner by the waterfront before watching the European soccer championship on TV. Ofer is part of a hiking group, so we joined the crew for their weekly Sunday hike. They are definitely in shape! We trekked through beautiful rainforest-like trails, passing waterfalls and swinging on vines. After a few hours we reached Kirstenbosh, the area's botanical gardens. We filled ourselves with cake and coffee before making our way back to a memorial monument near the cars. That night Ofer had a date, so Mark and I took the opportunity for our own. We went to the mall for the typical dinner and a movie. It was Mark's turn to choose, so we watched the new X-men. I fell asleep. Monday was the day all my South African dreams came true. I had arranged the event of a lifetime, and was willing to get up at 4:30 AM to do it. What was I so excited about, you may ask? ...GREAT WHITE SHARK CAGE DIVING!! After 3 hours of travel, a delicious breakfast, and a boat ride to "shark alley" (between "seal island" and Dyer island) the blood bath began! The sharks were tempted with giant chunks of bait, pieces of fish swirled into water and dumped overboard, and a styrofoam cutout of a seal named 'Henrietta' (who caught a shark tooth in her side during the first attack). We were given 7 mm wetsuits and goggles before entering the cage hanging from the side of the boat. With every pass of the sharks we would hold our breath and watch them come within inches of our face, attacking the well-placed bait. I went in the cage for three half-hour stints, despite the frigid water. It was too amazing not to. As we were heading back to mainland for food and to watch the movie, a shark jumped straight up out of the water. Absolutely incredible! And of course no boat ride is complete without Mark getting seasick. Five minutes before docking he filled a barf bag. After my time spent in shark alley, I am now confident that I will never go surfing in Cape Town. That night Ofer taught us to make shokshooka, an Israeli dish (Ofer is from Israel) made of spicy tomato soup and boiled eggs. Delicious. Tuesday Mark and I finally went into downtown Cape Town. We wandered Loop and Long, the shopping streets. We went to a tap house, saw the up-and-coming Woodstock neighborhood, and had a local beer at the Devils Peak Brewing Company. On Wednesday we met Ofer's business partner. They use a laser cutter to cut materials (records, cds, fabric, wood, etc) into things (clocks, coasters, jewelry, boxes, etc). It was amazing to watch the machine work and see the results. His partner (who was unfortunately making an urn for her father) even gave me a small wood cutout of Africa for a necklace. That afternoon we were passed on to our final hosts, Carole and Tony in Glencairn, one of the towns farthest south. Once their daughters moved to England they decided to start hosting travelers. The way to their house is over a stunning pass on a cliff over the ocean. Tony is a carpenter, and built their amazing and quirky home himself. The kitchen is built using part of the mountain as a wall, the upstairs bathrooms have glass roofs, and Tony built a lot of the furniture using teak wood from travels to Thailand. They treated us to a homemade South African dinner that was absolutely delicious. Moulva pudding... yes I got the recipe! The next day we walked up through the coastal towns along the beach, and took the train back to make our hosts our newly learned recipe: shokshooka. Friday was Mark's birthday! Carole made him a delicious cake and bag of goodies for our long bus ride back to Johannesburg. I took Mark out for sushi (his favorite) downtown. It pays to be near the water! Having broken our camera in a cave earlier in the week, we also bought a new one. We took the bus for a quick trip to the waterfront, an area of fun shops and restaurants. Then it was off on another 22-hour bus ride back to Johannesburg! The best way to end a birthday.

item.description: Flying to South Africa (cheaply) wasn't the most logical thing in the world. Uganda -> Rwanda -> Ethiopia -> S. Africa. We flew Ethiopian Air and decided that Ethiopians have a really cool language. Spoken, and (especially) written. We spent 2 nights in Joburg. The nights were spent inside our hostel because night time is a "no-go" in the city. Unless you're gangsta enough... which Laura and I are still trying to improve on. One of the days we just chilled, but the next day we spent at the
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: Flying to South Africa (cheaply) wasn't the most logical thing in the world. Uganda -> Rwanda -> Ethiopia -> S. Africa. We flew Ethiopian Air and decided that Ethiopians have a really cool language. Spoken, and (especially) written. We spent 2 nights in Joburg. The nights were spent inside our hostel because night time is a "no-go" in the city. Unless you're gangsta enough... which Laura and I are still trying to improve on. One of the days we just chilled, but the next day we spent at the Apartheid museum. It was huge and took us more than 4 hours to walk through. The museum had a special exhibit on Nelson Mandela as a tribute to his life and recent passing. While walking through we ran into Lorien, a friend of Laura's growing up. Small world. Next stop: Cape Town. 22 hours by bus. We're pro at traveling by now. Ain't no thang.

item.title: Come, Let's Dance - Nansana, Ugand
item.description: Our next stop was with an organization called 'Come, Let's Dance' in Nansana, Uganda. It was started by three locals and one westerner. CLD has a children's home, school, farm, clinic, and craft project/community center. Mark's friend Morgan has been involved with CLD for 7 years and is currently living at their volunteer house with his new bride. We were greeted by the volunteers, Morgan, Beth (his wife), and her delicious no-bake chocolate oatmeal cookies. Delicious. Our time was spent at
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Our next stop was with an organization called 'Come, Let's Dance' in Nansana, Uganda. It was started by three locals and one westerner. CLD has a children's home, school, farm, clinic, and craft project/community center. Mark's friend Morgan has been involved with CLD for 7 years and is currently living at their volunteer house with his new bride. We were greeted by the volunteers, Morgan, Beth (his wife), and her delicious no-bake chocolate oatmeal cookies. Delicious. Our time was spent at Thread of Life, the farm, or the school/clinic. All are a taxi ride away from 'base camp'. 'Thread of Life', CLD's sewing and craft project, is built as a community center near a major slum in Kampala. The community is welcome to use the beautiful plot of land for church meetings, picnics, whatever. TOL hosts weekly English class, sewing courses, and savings circles. There are also apartments on the property that they are renting out for income until TOL makes enough money to sustain all of its programs independently. The savings circles are set up so that each person commits to coming and bringing at least a small amount of money weekly. They record their savings in a book before giving the money and ledger to the three facilitators. The money and records are checked in front of the group. The group decides on the savings period (typically 6 months - 1 year. Those in the circle are allowed to take a loan out against the group pot that is less than or equal to double their contributions to-date. The group agrees on an interest rate that will be spread based on shares in the pot once the loan is repaid. Each member is given their total savings (plus interest) at the end of the savings period. This model has proven successful for CLD and is used at many of its projects. Women are found in the nearby slums for the sewing course. A patient teacher and lots of practice are key to the class' success. While with CLD, we were able to see a graduation ceremony for approximately 10 women. They all showed off the clothes they learned to make, made speeches thanking God and their class, and shared hopes for the future. All planned to continue practicing at TOL, and hope to get successful jobs as tailors. Of course I couldn't resist the excellent skills of the women and also the great prices. So after a shopping afternoon in Kampala and a few days of waiting, I took home a beautiful skirt...and a few things from their craft shop...while Mark fixed their solar power. The 'Double Portion Farm" is centered around a revolutionary way of farming called 'Farming God's Way'. This method is easy and beneficial for local farmers, as it is expected to produce 14x regular yield within seven seasons (Uganda is the only place where they can get 2 seasons per year). It also calls for work to be done by hand (not with expensive machinery), for utilizing pulled weeds and compost as a blanket for crops, and for the land to never be burned. The four principles of the program are: high standards, on time, with joy, and without wastage. Mark and I spent our time weeding (and laying the weeds back on the ground), and top dressing (digging small holes next to each corn stock to give vitamins to each plant). We were sore for days. Our evening at the farm consisted of playing with 2-day old goats, a puppy, and a fresh baby cow (which unfortunately died later in the week after ingesting a plastic bag). After a campfire, we went to bed under a giant shelter, using our bug net as a tent. All the Ugandans were shocked and thought we would freeze to death (it was an 80+ degree day). Sleeping was great until the storm hit. The wind blew the rain right into us, so we quickly shuffled around to a couple more locations before finding a dry place that would work. A farm really is a beautiful place to wake up (as long as you're not soaking wet). School was on break for the entire month we were in Uganda. This made visiting the school a bit boring, but still fun to see. The clinic proved to be exciting when a swarm of thousands of ants were discovered in the lab. Thankfully the neighborhood kids were good at stomping. Mark and I bought some de-worming pills (most volunteers in Uganda take them as a precaution every 3 months), as 9 months in the developing world is very likely to have given us something. Mark also took time to fix the clinic's electrical wiring, which was shoddily done back in the day. Mark met a guy named Peter when he first came to Uganda with CLD in 2008. They became friends working at the farm, and kept in touch on Facebook. Mark helped him out with a semester's tuition to go back to school after dropping out. Now, Peter just graduated as salutatorian of his high school! He is expected to get a full-ride scholarship to study civil engineering at a nearby university. All this to say, Peter came by with a friend to say hi to Mark, meet me, and eat some delicious dinner. Africa lived up to it's reputation of pests, as we received lots of mosquito bites (yes, we are on malaria pills), bed bugs from an infested chair in the house, and came away from the farm with new friends: jiggers (small white worms that burry themselves under your skin). Mark had one in his hand, and I had three on my feet. Thankfully Nurse Ana and her fancy needle work was able to teach us how to poke them - and their eggs - out. Side note: shampoo was VERY hard to find near Nansana. Hair oil: easy. Shampoo: hard. Conditioner: impossible. Reading my book "When Helping Hurts", remembering my college 3rd World Development class, talking to people, and visiting non-profits has us thinking more about the right way to go about aid in the developing world. This means lots of research into where our money is going. We don't have the answers yet, but are enjoying the process.

item.title: Safari! - Masindi, Uganda
item.description: (Self note: We actually split up our time at Come Let's Dance (see next blog) by taking a safari on one of the weekends) Mark and I had compared packages, asked for advice, and looked forward to our Ugandan safari for weeks. Merchison National Park, we were told, is the place to go. We teamed up with Brin (who we met at Musana), and her visiting mom, to make the ultimate 4-person safari dream team. After a 4-hour bus ride from Kampala to Masindi, we checked into our adorable cottage at the New
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: (Self note: We actually split up our time at Come Let's Dance (see next blog) by taking a safari on one of the weekends) Mark and I had compared packages, asked for advice, and looked forward to our Ugandan safari for weeks. Merchison National Park, we were told, is the place to go. We teamed up with Brin (who we met at Musana), and her visiting mom, to make the ultimate 4-person safari dream team. After a 4-hour bus ride from Kampala to Masindi, we checked into our adorable cottage at the New Court View Hotel (recommended by Ryan and Sarah, our friends in Burundi). A pleasant break from community living. We met our private driver, Moses, who insisted that he could call any guide in the park to talk about sightings and take us to all the animals in the park the next day. I didn't sleep well and woke up with a 'hokey tummy'. Translated: I skipped the complimentary breakfast. We made the 1.5 hour dirt road drive into the park, and to the ferry - just in time to miss the 9AM crossing. Finding ourselves with an hour and a half to kill, we picked up some sandwiches and enjoyed the peaceful view of the Nile. Once on the other side, the safari began! Taking off down the dirt road, Moses led us through the game park. Elephants, giraffes, water buffalo, birds, cobys, and a bunch of animals new to me passed within feet of our red pickup. It was absolutely incredible to see animals in their natural habitats. Giraffes are much taller than what I remember from the zoo. The only things we didn't feast our eyes on were the big cats. Turns out Moses wasn't completely honest with us the night before, as another group at our hotel was able to see both cats. I guess that's the luck of the draw! My cramping stomach evolved throughout the day into frequent trips to the bathroom, cramps, and a fever. I'll spare you further details. The feeling was eerily familiar to the delightful sickness I had in Thailand, India and Nepal. Knowing it was better to avoid food rather than wake up hugging the toilet, I fasted the rest of the day. Determined to enjoy the rest of my first safari, we moved on to visit a swanky river-view hotel and then to the famous Merchison Falls. We were shocked at the amount of water powering through a narrow canyon. It was absolutely incredible. When we got back, I spent the night watching Aliens 2 on our Ipad (a much better movie than I expected). Feeling spoiled by a bit of luxury, we made our way back to Kampala by bus. We continued the vacation by visiting The Little Donkey restaurant to get our Mexican food fix. Satisfied and feeling better from the Mexican food 'medicine', we took a taxi van back to our friends at Come Let's Dance (see next blog).

item.title: Rafting the Nile River - Jinja, Uganda
item.description: Mark has talked about rafting the Nile River for years. He would always say things like "rafting the Nile is way more intense than this" (during any water activity), or reminisce with friends about the exhilarating experience. Even though he had already rafted it twice in 2008, Mark felt it imperative to take me down the Nile during our time in Uganda. I quickly and enthusiastically agreed. We left Musana early Friday morning with Pat (a retired Canadian with a zest for adventure), and Yvonne
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Mark has talked about rafting the Nile River for years. He would always say things like "rafting the Nile is way more intense than this" (during any water activity), or reminisce with friends about the exhilarating experience. Even though he had already rafted it twice in 2008, Mark felt it imperative to take me down the Nile during our time in Uganda. I quickly and enthusiastically agreed. We left Musana early Friday morning with Pat (a retired Canadian with a zest for adventure), and Yvonne (another Canadian who was terrified to join us, but ready to cross it off her bucket list). After a matatu ride (white taxi vans that go everywhere in Uganda, holding 14+ people) we transferred to a giant raft-mobile. The raft-mobile's structure was obviously built in Uganda, with enough engine power to tow a few dozen people and rafts for all. We tore down local streets for an hour, making our way past a newly-built dam to the start of our epic adventure. We were joined in our raft by Robert, a 20-something oil digging Polish man, and Hassan, a 20-something local guide. After convincing Yvonne and Robert that "extreme" was the correct choice for the day, we tore off down the class 4 and 5 rapids. The rapids included a 15+ foot waterfall, falls in the river resulting in significant time underwater (we were instructed to ball up and "find your happy place") until re-surfacing, and paddling into giant waves. Paddling through the waves made me feel like a pirate on the open sea. But for the sake of the raft, it is a good thing none of us had peg legs or hook hands. Halfway through the day we reached a rapid called "the bad place". We somehow made it through, but there was one casualty: Yvonne's big toenail. Ouch. We were given breakfast, lunch on the river (pineapples and crackers), and an absolutely epic barbecue at the end of the day. Vegetable curry, rolls, hummus, potatoes, some of the best beef of my life (next to my parent's blue cheese steak), and an open bar. Happy, exhausted, and full, we went back to the riverside Nile River Explorers hostel. We spent the evening talking to a couple from South Africa (the next county on our list), and now have a "br-eye" (BBQ) to look forward to in Johannesburg. We spent the next day relaxing in Jinja. Wandering town, looking at art, catching up on the internet, and eating some amazing food (including a legit Indian dinner).

item.title: Musana - Iganga, Kigali, Uganda
item.description: Our travel time from Kigali to Iganga was a good 16 hours using all transfer means available: Taxi to bus to minivan (with a record 22 people inside) to boda (motorbike taxi). But everything went as smooth as it can, as far as ground transportation in Africa is concerned. The reason we trekked our way up to Iganga was to visit our friend AP. She started a community development organization there called Musana when I first visited Uganda in 2008. It's freaking awesome. They have all sorts of
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: Our travel time from Kigali to Iganga was a good 16 hours using all transfer means available: Taxi to bus to minivan (with a record 22 people inside) to boda (motorbike taxi). But everything went as smooth as it can, as far as ground transportation in Africa is concerned. The reason we trekked our way up to Iganga was to visit our friend AP. She started a community development organization there called Musana when I first visited Uganda in 2008. It's freaking awesome. They have all sorts of things going on. A primary school, dormitories, dairy farm, restaurant, etc. They also conduct micro-loans for women, are building a secondary school, and a mushroom farm. Their O&M budget is 70% sustainable and growing. Ok - enough of the sales pitch, but here's a link to their website if you're interested: musana.org AP is now married to an awesome Ugandan dude named Haril. They are living in Iganga most of the time managing Musana. Our goal was to provide help with any sort of grunt work needed. Which really meant playing with the kids, digging ditches, and tagging along on village meetings. Playing with the kids was probably more exhausting than digging ditches. Even though I grew up playing soccer, I got completely destroyed by children 15 years younger than me. They literally dribbled around me and through me. If we weren't playing soccer, they were braiding our hair or asking us to supervise them in the computer lab. Most of our ditch digging was to divert water drainage away from Musana's fish farm, as the dirty (trash) water was killing the fish. We also helped make fish food. Yep, fish food. How many people have the privilege of saying they've done that! Last were village meetings, which were centered around micro-loans and business development. Especially for the women. Laura actually had a dress made by one of the ladies who was hired on by Musana. On Sunday we went to a local church service that most of the Musana staff goes to. The music was LOOOOOOUUDD. It's almost like a competition to see which church can worship louder than the other. We also had a nice conversation with the local teachers. In Ugandan culture, you're not a man unless you have a baby. Therefore they encouraged me to "plant the seed" before we go home and surprise everybody. After a few laughs, one of the men insisted that we trade wives for fun. His wife seemed to be legitimately on board with the idea (polygamy here is fairly normal as well). But Ugandan woman are used to receiving a dowry (which I told her I did not pay for Laura), therefore she immediately lost all interest in the idea. Not to mention we're monogomists. On that happy note - I will end this blog entry. Off to Jinja for Nile River Rafting!

item.title: Rwanda - Kigali, Rwanda
item.description: At the airport on the way to Kigali, Rwanda, Mark and I were again given trouble about being siblings. The man checking us in told us that we couldn't be married, as we have the same last name. After denying incest and explaining that my last name used to be 'Bischoff', he finally believed us. When checking my bag, he referred to it as "mama's" bag. He insisted that we would have babies soon. Mark was also asked by a few people if he would be speaking at the genocide 20 year anniversary
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: At the airport on the way to Kigali, Rwanda, Mark and I were again given trouble about being siblings. The man checking us in told us that we couldn't be married, as we have the same last name. After denying incest and explaining that my last name used to be 'Bischoff', he finally believed us. When checking my bag, he referred to it as "mama's" bag. He insisted that we would have babies soon. Mark was also asked by a few people if he would be speaking at the genocide 20 year anniversary remembrance activities going on in Rwanda. Apparently his long hair (somehow) gives him an air of professionalism. Elias was a little trooper during the 30-minute flight. Rwanda is clean, organized, and even has traffic lights with a count-down system (although it does get stuck at "0" a lot). It is considered one of the least corrupt and most forward-moving countries in Africa. Our guest house was beautiful. It had an amazing view overlooking the city, and included a delicious buffet breakfast each morning. Friday was Elias' day for shots. We all went to a small clinic in the Belgian Embassy, where he entered with his parents to brave the needles. Mark and I wandered the block until we found some giant terradactyl-looking birds in a giant grass field on the other side of a fence. Mark took a few photos before I noticed a man with a bug gun and an angry face coming toward us. He asked why we were taking pictures of the government house, declaring sternly that "we have a problem". Thankfully he soon realized that we were just clueless tourists, and let us go on our merry way. Next stop was a mall for diapers and coffee. There was a movie theater on the top floor. Mark and I went to check out the day's movies, but found that none were listed on the screens. After a wait we were handed a printed piece of paper from deep inside a drawer, boasting five movies and times. How To Train Your Dragon 2 wasn't on the list (we were hoping it was because the first movie is awesome), and we hadn't heard of any of the other movies, so we decided to pass. Lunch was BURRITOS! A man who had worked for a California Chipotle started up a restaurant in town. It was the same idea, but also included options for goat meat and pineapple/mango salsa. Guacamole was free, but sour cream cost extra - opposite of home. Lucky Africa...able to grow everything! That afternoon we visited the Rwanda Trading Company. They're a local company that processes and packages coffee for places like Folger's and Starbucks (among other places). They were closed, but a nice guy from Arkansas was in his office to show us around. On Saturday we went to the Rwanda Genocide Museum. Here is a link to a site with a short history of the genocide if you want to read up: http://history1900s.about.com/od/rwandangenocide/a/Rwanda-Genocide.htm The museum was packed because we were there during the 20th anniversary month. Entrance is free, as they want everyone to come. Inside the building you are led to walk along a timeline of the events leading up to the genocide. Next is a history of the killings, and also an area to honor the victims with personal pictures hanging on the walls. We also passed through a room highlighting personal details of the children who were killed. The top floor included an exhibit on genocide in general, including definitions and other examples throughout history. The Rwandans keep the genocide discussion in the open. Memorials are also intentionally set up as places to teach children. They want to keep discussions going to prevent something similar from ever happening again. Hutus and Tutsis (the two groups that clashed in the genocide) are no longer distinguished in society. We were really impressed. On the flip side, there are rumors of the government in Burundi training child soldiers in preparation for the upcoming 2015 elections. People in Burundi are generally less educated, and still identify as Hutu or Tutsi. Chatter and speculations are swirling, everyone is hoping that a similar genocide is not on the horizon for Burundi. In the afternoon we went for a drink at the hotel from the movie "Hotel Rwanda", where Mille Colline, a wealthy and well-known owner of the hotel hid hundreds of Tutsis during the genocide. You can get a cocktail named after him there. Highly recommend it. Sunday was Easter. We all went to a local church with lots of singing. It was just over 2 hours long, which is considered exceptionally short for an African church. After we were stopped in the parking lot by a local news station (who had been filming the church service) to say a few words about Easter and Rwanda. We were famous on the local news that night! We went for one last burrito (couldn't resist!) before saying goodbye to Ryan, Sarah, and Elias. They were absolutely amazing hosts and tour guides. Luckily they are also moving back to Boulder in 3 weeks, so we're looking forward to seeing them again soon! Mark and I stayed one more night before catching the 6AM bus the following morning to Iganga, Uganda.

item.title: Guinea Pigs at the Museum - Bujumbura, Kigali, Burundi
item.description: Our last day in Bujumbura was spent at Musee Vivant, the "museum" in town. Except it proved to be more of a makeshift zoo than a museum. On our drive there, along the lake, we were greeted by a bloat (yes, a bloat) of hippos. They were ENORMOUS! And every time their heads poked up through the water, their ears would spin and shake to get the water off. It was very entertaining. We arrived at Musee Vivant, not knowing that the next hour would be among the more entertaining - and emotional - so
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Our last day in Bujumbura was spent at Musee Vivant, the "museum" in town. Except it proved to be more of a makeshift zoo than a museum. On our drive there, along the lake, we were greeted by a bloat (yes, a bloat) of hippos. They were ENORMOUS! And every time their heads poked up through the water, their ears would spin and shake to get the water off. It was very entertaining. We arrived at Musee Vivant, not knowing that the next hour would be among the more entertaining - and emotional - so far in Burundi. We were joined by a guide who gave us a tour of the grounds. We were shown crocodiles and alligators in cages with walls that seemed just a tiny bit too low. He assured us they were fine, and that they add bricks or taller fences as the animals grew bigger. He also told us about Gustov, the ginormous crocodile terror who is responsible for killing about 300 people in the nearby lake. He has been missing for a few years, presumedly to wreak havoc on the Congo side of the lake. We saw one aquarium of local fish, some monkeys, and a leopard eating a baby cow before being led to the snake house. Our guide detailed information about each snake, holding a few and offering them to us. A couple cages, including one holding live (thankfully non-venomous) snakes, had broken glass. One damaged cage was the result to over-eager children, and the other was from the zoo's chimpanzee who got upset, was somehow let loose, and went on a rampage. The last stop was the chimpanzee, swinging on a tire swing in her cage. As soon as she saw us (namely Elias) approaching, she jumped off and greeted us, hand out of the cage. She reached for Elias and gently held his foot. No reaction from him. As the responsible parents backed up (images of the woman mauled on Oprah in their heads), the chimpanzee made an overly-dramatic sad face. She tried to lure Ryan with a stick to bring Elias back. Her efforts unsuccessful, she chucked the stick at Ryan and swung madly around her cage. Before we left, we were offered a cage full of guinea pigs and rabbits to feed to the leopard or one of the many crocodiles. The men (Mark and Ryan) looked at each other and gave in, to the horror of Sarah and I. Thankfully Elias was asleep by now and missed the following chaos. A guinea pig was selected (with some squealing), and used by our guide to tease every animal we passed. Finally we arrived at the big croc's cage, where the guinea pig was used to tease him until we insisted that he put the little guy out of his misery. Our guide tossed the animal into the water, and it was quickly chomped by the crocodile mid-swim. All four of us left traumatized. That was one strange museum.

item.title: Kayanza: Field Visits - Kayanza, Kigali, Burundi
item.description: Ryan works for Hope International, a micro-finance NGO that works to bring savings plans to the poor areas of the world. Burundi is the third poorest country in the world (according to some guy on the internet), under Zimbabwe and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (which can be seen across the lake from Bujumbura). Over half the population lives on less than $1.25 a day. Hope works with local churches to bring up leaders in the community to create savings groups. Burundi culture is very
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Ryan works for Hope International, a micro-finance NGO that works to bring savings plans to the poor areas of the world. Burundi is the third poorest country in the world (according to some guy on the internet), under Zimbabwe and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (which can be seen across the lake from Bujumbura). Over half the population lives on less than $1.25 a day. Hope works with local churches to bring up leaders in the community to create savings groups. Burundi culture is very hospitable. If someone asks you for a loan and you have the money, you are culturally required to give it. The savings groups keep this in mind. Once a week the groups meet, each person bringing a set small amount of money. The money is pooled, and given to one member who immediately goes and buys something to make profit off of (a bag of food to re-sell, a down-payment on a store, a goat, etc). The member who gets the pot rotates weekly, so the group benefits each member. There is also another savings plan used in which group can pool money and choose to loan money to any one member if they feel the person can pay it back. Interest rates and payback period are determined by the group. Ryan, Sarah, Elias, and a friendly local Hope employee named Belize, took us out to Kayanza, a 2-hour drive into the hills. The plan was to visit some savings groups and see what they have been able to do. As soon as we left town, the poverty of Burundi became more apparent. On our way up, bike riders carrying water up to their homes hitched rides by holding onto the backs trucks. There could be 7+ riders nonchalantly holding onto one truck. On the way we bought two GIANT avocados (the size of large mangoes). They were delicious. We were greeted by the leader in Kayanza, who showed us around to different areas of town. Each project was shown to us by the project leader, and two other prominent people in the group. We were shown a bee hive project, a pig project, a chicken project, and a store financed through a loan from his group. The road was too washed out (and the new home of a giant fallen tree) to see the goat project, but the dozens of goats around town satisfied our goat quota for the month. It really was amazing to see what the simple savings plans allowed people to accomplish. You could see pride in their eyes as they talked about their projects' success. It was really encouraging to see such hope. The people in this region are extremely conservative Christians, so we were asked to remove all jewelry before going. Being foreigners, it was ok to have our hair done. But local women either wear headscarves or sport chic buzz cuts. We were completely swarmed by kids, wanting to touch our skin or practice the little english they learned in school. They especially found baby Elias entertaining. He was passed along from woman to woman, a big smile on his face. At one of our stops, while entertaining the kids so Sarah could breastfeed, we were approached through the crowd of giggling children by a drunk woman, yelling in Kurundi (the local language), throwing her head back, and blazing all her teeth in a crazed cackle. No one in town seemed surprised, and just shuffled her on her way. It was like something out of a movie. After a long and tiring day, we went to Cafe Gourmond (the French bakery in Bujumbura) for a delicious meal of paninis, cole slaw, juice, and pastries. Full and feeling better, we walked out to the car. There were about a dozen police officers with rifles surrounding it. Apparently the place we were directed to park in was not a parking space. It is required to parallel park on this particular street, even though other cars were parked as we were, and there was a car parked a stones-throw away under a sign on the sidewalk. Ryan's usual strategy of pretending not to know a word of French (everyone on Bujumbura speaks French and the local language, Kirundi) failed when the officer proved to be fluent in English. A $30 ticket later, we were back at home in bed. Ryan was glad it was only $30.

item.title: Mzungus Reunited at Last - Bujumbura, Burundi
item.description: Mark and I arrived in the Bujumbura, Burundi airport after stops in Ethiopia, Uganda (which our airline added last-minute to combine two flights into one), and Rwanda. Walking away from the plane, we felt like we were in a movie. In the distance were beautiful green hills, the air smelled amazing, and the weather was perfect. Unfortunately the fairytale ended quickly at the visa counter, where we were informed that we could only pay in US dollars. They didn't take Visa, Mastercard, or even their
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Mark and I arrived in the Bujumbura, Burundi airport after stops in Ethiopia, Uganda (which our airline added last-minute to combine two flights into one), and Rwanda. Walking away from the plane, we felt like we were in a movie. In the distance were beautiful green hills, the air smelled amazing, and the weather was perfect. Unfortunately the fairytale ended quickly at the visa counter, where we were informed that we could only pay in US dollars. They didn't take Visa, Mastercard, or even their own local currency. This was a new one for us. Thankfully Ryan magically showed up to greet us at the desk, somehow going reverse through security without a ticket. They offered to keep our passports overnight so we could bring USD the next day, but Ryan wasn't sure our passports would still be there. We tried to exchange some local currency at the airport, but were offered a rate much, much worse than advertised on the board. When pushed, the woman said "we are the black market". The nearby cop didn't care and said she was the one to decide the rate. In the end we paid for one visa using dollars I had with me, and the other in local currency (after some persuasion) with a slightly less-bad exchange rate at the visa counter directly. Ryan drove us to his house where we were greeted by his wife, Sarah, and their absolutely adorable 3-month-old, Elias. The three of them bravely volunteered to spend the next two weeks with us. They live in a really nice 4-bedroom house in a gated compound guarded round-the-clock by three guards: one during the day and two at night. They also have an amazingly friendly house help named Emilianne. She does not speak English, but is very animated and gifted at charades. She has 2 of her own and 3 orphans at home. The guards and Emilianne stopped Mark and I at different times to ask if we were siblings. Mark had to make good on his wedding vows and insist that we are, in fact, married. Emilianne said she would pray to Jesus that we have babies. Mark and I pray to Jesus that we don't (yet) have babies. When we arrived, Mark and I were fed an amazing dinner by Sarah, who filled our stomaches our whole stay in Burundi with absolutely delicious home-cooked meals. Thankfully she taught me most of them, so I have some new recipes to try at home! Chickpea burgers, steaks, pasta casserole, quinoa burrito bowls... Food was much more expensive than we expected, especially in the main city of Bujumbura (where street food is not a thing). A lot of groceries, especially for cooking "western" meals, are imported and spread throughout different stores in town. Fruits and veggies are all washed (by Sarah) in a diluted bleach mixture to ward off any parasites. We even got to start every day with french press Burundi coffee and a chocolate croissant thanks to a nearby French bakery! As the ATMs in Burundi give terrible rates or are broken, Ryan took us on a field trip to his bank, where after some magic with our credit card, an hour and a half, and a $12 hidden fee, we were finally given $300 cash in US dollars. Only then were we able to get the "ok" black market rate at a nearby foreign exchange shop. With money in our hands Ryan and Sarah dropped us off downtown to get a feel for the city and people. Like every new country we visit, it took a few minutes to get used to being the only white people ("mzungus") in sight. I even got about three people pointing and stating "mzungu!" to their friends, something I am told will be much more common in Uganda. Technically, mzungu means "white wanderer." We went through a bunch of shops (which were small sheds) filled with masks and artifacts from the DRC, just across the lake from town. They were slightly creepy, especially the ones with fake hair, and were also home to numerous spiders. We picked up a SIM card, bananas, and passion fruit before making the short walk home in the afternoon heat. We spent the first few days relaxing at the Severns' house. Internet, a hot shower, shopping trips, and wonderfully delicious food. We even had time to sit down and watch the movies Crash (HIGHLY recommend), and Sweeny Todd (...unique, but I don't recommend). Having an energetic baby like Elias to play with and smile at all the time made the re-charge time even better. Since Americans (and Westerners in general) are a rare breed, we were invited to a US embassy party thrown by an athletic couple (he is in the military) and their kids. The shin-dig took place at their beautiful home on a hill outside town. Their yard was decked out with a slackline, volleyball net, swimming pool, and personal cook roasting a whole lamb under the gazeebo. Somehow about half of the people in attendance were from Colorado, so it was good to feel a bit like we were at home. Feeling inspired, Mark and I braved the embassy the next morning to get more pages in my passport. It was enormous! Armed guards, triple security, guards to chaperone you from place to place...they didn't even permit anyone to walk on the front sidewalk - you were required to pass to the other side of the street. A few days later we joined in an embassy softball game in a field next to where the president plays soccer. I'm not sure how there were 20 gloves and 3 bats available, but Mark and I had fun getting our exercise on. Even with my expert slow-pitching, Mark's team somehow won. No sport game in a foreign country is complete without Mark injuring himself - he came away with a messed up knee from ramming into the catcher at home plate. He didn't knock the catcher over (a ginormous marine). So yes... he was out. He's a little sore, but expected to make a full recovery :) Ryan's birthday fell in the middle of our stay. We celebrated by going out to a nice meal on one of the hills overlooking town. It felt a lot like the Flagstaff House, but the prices were much easier on the wallet. Beautiful AND delicious. We absolutely loved our time in Bujumbura. It was great to see friends and have time to relax, while still living in a completely new culture. Ryan and Sarah were EXTREMELY hospitable, making us feel right at home. As Mark so eloquently stated, "this is the most at-home I have felt in months".

item.title: Home Again - Tel Aviv, Israel
item.description: Back on our cozy porch downtown Tel Aviv, we found ourselves yet again spoiled by Lev and Natalka. I stepped on a cross-eyed, autistic cat in the apartment stairwell (apparently a common occurrence, as he tries to run in front of residents). Thankfully for my conscience, I found him the next day, happy and with no fresh wounds, to apologize. After a failed attempt to pay for a delicious dinner of sushi and Thai food at the Tel Aviv Pier (Lev is stronger and speaks more Hebrew than us), we
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Back on our cozy porch downtown Tel Aviv, we found ourselves yet again spoiled by Lev and Natalka. I stepped on a cross-eyed, autistic cat in the apartment stairwell (apparently a common occurrence, as he tries to run in front of residents). Thankfully for my conscience, I found him the next day, happy and with no fresh wounds, to apologize. After a failed attempt to pay for a delicious dinner of sushi and Thai food at the Tel Aviv Pier (Lev is stronger and speaks more Hebrew than us), we decided to make a Mexican feast for them on our last night. Natalka insisted on packing us snacks whenever we went out, so we were armed with fresh fruit and delicious home baked muffins for our last day in town. We ran errands, then bought flowers, magnum bars (necessary for any Mexican meal), every vegetable in the store, and even found tortillas! We definitely over-bought, but ended up with a meal that reminded Mark and I of home. One of our new friends from scuba diving, Danny, was able to come over and help eat, too. We were given the honor of sampling a taste of the vodka that Natalka's grandpa makes in Ukraine. Both her and Lev don't like it, so samples are reserved for guests. It wasn't as bad as they set it up to be. After feasting they brought us to the train station to begin our journey to the far-off land of Burundi, Africa!

item.title: Red Sea Diving - Eilat, Israel
item.description: Eilat was a world of it's own. The pale desert of both Eilat and Aqaba (the Jordanian city on the other side of the sea) made the deep blue of the Red Sea POP. Unfortunately despite it's name, the sea is not red (the name comes from the red of the nearby mountains). The city is built for tourism - both local and international, as seen by fancy hotels and expensive restaurants. When we went to the grocery store we were asked to show our passports. Odd. Then we were required to pay 5 shekels into
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Eilat was a world of it's own. The pale desert of both Eilat and Aqaba (the Jordanian city on the other side of the sea) made the deep blue of the Red Sea POP. Unfortunately despite it's name, the sea is not red (the name comes from the red of the nearby mountains). The city is built for tourism - both local and international, as seen by fancy hotels and expensive restaurants. When we went to the grocery store we were asked to show our passports. Odd. Then we were required to pay 5 shekels into the grocery cart, a deposit to be returned upon putting the cart back in place after shopping. This is common throughout the whole country. Mark and I settled into our hostel, soon to be joined by eight Israelis (including Lev and Natalka). After a late dinner it was off to bed. We shared a room with a guy named Nimrod (be sure to say it with an Israeli accent) and his beautiful golden retriever, Mika. Thank goodness for allergy pills! Our first day was spent at the beach with our new roommates, Lev, and Natalka. The water was cold, and Mika could not be satisfied playing fetch no matter how many times her ball was thrown into the water. That night we all went out to a shnazzy dinner at a steakhouse. And the next day....SCUBA DIVING!! Our large group all went out to dive at a reef off shore (beautiful) and also at a sunken missile boat. Thankfully the missiles were removed. The boat dive was one of the best we have done so far on our trip. It was fun to explore inside, visibility was exceptional, and the swarms of fish were absolutely incredible. After diving we were given a VIP ride back to Tel Aviv with Nimrod. He took us the scenic route past Egypt's border, through the desert, and to an absolutely enormous crater viewpoint. He taught us about Israel's history of neighboring attacks, and we taught him about the USA's confusing government.

item.title: The Land of Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade - Ma'an, Jordan
item.description: But we didn't find the holy grail! Al Khazneh (the temple housing the grail in the movie) is not very big inside. The movie lies! Surprise? But it was definitely one of the coolest things we've seen so far. Quick facts (I don't take any responsibility for being wrong about these. item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: But we didn't find the holy grail! Al Khazneh (the temple housing the grail in the movie) is not very big inside. The movie lies! Surprise? But it was definitely one of the coolest things we've seen so far. Quick facts (I don't take any responsibility for being wrong about these. Laura and I aren't very good at listening to guides): Al Khazneh, or "The Treasury" is actually a mausoleum in the center of Petra, Jordan. Petra is an ancient city hand-carved out of sandstone. There is only one entrance to the city via a long and winding canyon. This made it easy to protect. It was also a major economic hub for the area. The city has passed through many people groups over time. The Nabataeans were the first, and the ones who did most of the carving, including the Al Khazneh. Then they were taken over by the Romans (of course). The Roman architecture in Petra is more "built" rather than "carved". More recently, the Beduins have occupied the area and are the people selling you tourist junk or trying to get you to ride their camels. Due to multiple earthquakes, a good chunk of the city is buried underground/destroyed. The city had its own aqueduct system, a theatre, and tons of "grave caves" (I can't remember the proper name). Basically the whole time you're saying, "How did they carve that?". It's awesome. Highly recommended from Laura and I. After Petra we caught an all you can eat buffet (included with the tour). I had probably 100 lamb meatballs with spaghetti. I'm officially converted from beef to lamb when it comes to meatballs. Cows rejoice! Sorry vegetarians. It's soooo good. After lunch we took a 2 hour journey back to the Jordan-Israeli boarder where we met our Israeli friends who took a trip down to Eilat for the weekend to go scuba diving. Of course we had to partake! The area is famous for it.

item.title: Aqaba: Welcome to Jordan - Aqaba, Galilee, Jordan
item.description: From Jerusalem we took the 7AM bus south to the city of Eliat, next to the Red Sea. We then spent the day catching up on some reading, waiting for a 6PM pickup for our tour to Petra, Jordan. We researched and found that a tour group was cheaper than going alone, and spending the night before the tour in Aqaba, Jordan saved even more on the park entrance fee to Petra ($75 instead of $150). item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: From Jerusalem we took the 7AM bus south to the city of Eliat, next to the Red Sea. We then spent the day catching up on some reading, waiting for a 6PM pickup for our tour to Petra, Jordan. We researched and found that a tour group was cheaper than going alone, and spending the night before the tour in Aqaba, Jordan saved even more on the park entrance fee to Petra ($75 instead of $150). After avoiding a scamming taxi driver (with the tour company) who was trying to charge us a $15 fee for paying in local Israeli sheckles instead of dollars, we crossed the border into Jordan on foot. We were greeted by our guide on the other side, who had to talk to the head honcho of the taxi monopoly (in Jordan) and show him the stickers on our shirts in order to pass. We met a friendly couple at the border who wanted to catch a ride with us, but our guide explained that the taxi company does not allow anyone to drive with a tour company unless they have a sticker and also a guide present. Everyone else has to pay hefty transport fees, and groups are required to split up to be only one person per taxi. This is part of the reason we didn't try to go to Petra on our own... Mark and I entered the giant tourist bus and learned that we were the only ones staying overnight before the tour. We were brought to our downtown Aqaba hotel and told to be in the lobby at 8:30 AM. After seeing our beautiful room (that unfortunately smelled of smoke - everyone smokes in Jordan) and hearing about the wonderful breakfast buffet, we walked to the guide-recommended hummus restaurant up the street. Hummus is famous in Jordan, and for good reason. We were also served fresh orange juice, french fries and shwarma/cheese burritos. YUM. Our extremely friendly waiter refused our tip, but after some insistence gave in and said he would give the tip to someone who needs it (we'll take him for his word). Then we tried the local beer before going for a walk. Surprisingly, the Islamic state of Jordan does have beer. We were pleasantly surprised by how nice all the locals were. One teenager literally chauffered us across traffic, while another man in a car leaned out his window and apologized when the driver didn't stop for us. Mark also made friends with a group of four teenage boys, who stopped their bikes to say "welcome to Jordan" and small talk. Everyone says "you are welcome in Jordan". We ran into a few camels on the sidewalks, and also a funny 11-year-old kid who started chasing us with a box of goods, jabbering in Jordanian. When Mark told him, "I bet you're trying to sell me something", his response was "YES! Very good!". Then he offered us a cigarette. Again, everyone smokes. We saw the Red Sea from the Jordanian side before turning in for the night.

item.title: Annoying Day - Jerusalem, Galilee, Israel
item.description: Our last day in Jerusalem was a mess. We tried to see the sights that had so-far eluded our schedule, including the Dome of the Rock (a holy place for Muslims and Jews), and the location where Jesus was betrayed in the Garden of Gethsemane. Unfortunately both were closed for lunch from 12-2:30. We got lunch and did a bit of shopping / meandering to kill time. item.content:encoded: Our last day in Jerusalem was a mess. We tried to see the sights that had so-far eluded our schedule, including the Dome of the Rock (a holy place for Muslims and Jews), and the location where Jesus was betrayed in the Garden of Gethsemane. Unfortunately both were closed for lunch from 12-2:30. We got lunch and did a bit of shopping / meandering to kill time. At 2:30 we tried four security points, all refusing us entry to the Dome of the Rock. One that we had entered earlier in the week now held a guard that informed us it was no longer an entry point. One held about 300 school kids. Another two only let in Muslims. We finally made it inside with 45 minutes before closing for the day. Listening to our audio tour on warp speed, we almost finished before being rudely forced out of the compound. We then went to the place Jesus was likely betrayed, and also visited the Church of Dominus Flevit, one of my favorite churches. It overlooked Jerusalem on the Mount of Olives, was small and cozy, and had great acoustics. From there we booked it to the light rial to see the Holocaust museum before closing. Upon arrival 30 minutes later, we were told that even though their sign and website say closing is at 5, they don't let anyone enter past 4, almost exactly when we arrived. We were, however, allowed to see the hall of remembrance for children, a small art exhibit, and a lecture hall. The hall of remembrance for children was one of the most impactful that we had ever seen. The room was filled with mirrors, reflecting candle flames throughout the whole room. As you walked through the maze, children's' names were read, along with their countries and age of death. We were sad to not see the rest of the museum, but still glad we came. Tired and annoyed about the day, we headed back to Old City. The post office we needed to visit was closed, so we decided to get ice cream. Unfortunately they didn't take credit card, and after getting cash we were told that we couldn't eat in the store because prices are different for dine-in. The ice cream was OK, but disappointing compared to the amazing concoction we were given in Tel Aviv. For our last night in Jerusalem we decided to sleep on the roof of a youth hostel in Old Jerusalem. It had amazing views, and came complete with mattress and fresh blankets. Thankfully we had our sleeping bags, too, because between the wind and the cold that had been slowly creeping in all week, it was about 40 degrees. We were warm enough, and able to get up at 5:30 to catch our bus to Eilat.

item.description: We booked our second guided Israel tour, jumping into a van with a bunch of Americans and Canadians to go up north to Nazareth. Our guide was more fluent in german than english. This meant that almost every english sentence he started would inevitably end up in enthusiastic and lengthly german. Thankfully at least the german-speaking half of our group could understand! On the drive we also saw the future location of Armageddon (not the 1998 film), and the Mount of Transfiguration. We stopped at
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We booked our second guided Israel tour, jumping into a van with a bunch of Americans and Canadians to go up north to Nazareth. Our guide was more fluent in german than english. This meant that almost every english sentence he started would inevitably end up in enthusiastic and lengthly german. Thankfully at least the german-speaking half of our group could understand! On the drive we also saw the future location of Armageddon (not the 1998 film), and the Mount of Transfiguration. We stopped at numerous churches, one with beautiful mosaic art pieces donning the walls, donated from different countries. Don't worry, the USA's contribution was the coolest. We saw St. Peter's house (an impressive site of excavated ruins), and an ancient house that was more like a maze of underground caves that is said to have been Mary and Joseph's. We tried to walk on water at the beautiful Sea of Galilee, and of course failed miserably. We also stopped at the Jordan River, and I had Mark baptize me. Might as well get baptized where Jesus did huh? Unfortunately the water was not beautiful like the Sea of Galilee, but rather cold, green, and full of GIANT fish! Still awesome.

item.title: O Little Town of Bethlehem - Bethlehem, Jerusalem, West Bank and Gaza
item.description: Our visit to Bethlehem fell on a Sunday, so we thought we'd check out a church service in Jerusalem before catching the bus. Walking through the old city, we found Christ Church - the oldest Protestant church in the Middle East. This church also had awesome acoustics so it was fun to sing in there with everyone. And the congregation was truly international, which made it even better. Boulder, Colorado would be jealous of our diversity. After church, we caught the bus to Bethlehem in the West
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: Our visit to Bethlehem fell on a Sunday, so we thought we'd check out a church service in Jerusalem before catching the bus. Walking through the old city, we found Christ Church - the oldest Protestant church in the Middle East. This church also had awesome acoustics so it was fun to sing in there with everyone. And the congregation was truly international, which made it even better. Boulder, Colorado would be jealous of our diversity. After church, we caught the bus to Bethlehem in the West Bank, following advice from a friendly American couple at church who work at the Garden Tomb. It definitely has a different feel than Israel proper. If anything, most of the writing is in Arabic rather than Hebrew. Laura and I grabbed our usual shawarma burritos and then moseyed our way over to the Church of Nativity. It was kind of disappointing... Church clergy yell, "Silence!" at all of the tourists while other clergy sing hymns in the corner. But you're not allowed to watch them... I'll refrain from being too harsh on them, but I guess Laura and I have different views on how God works. A little upset, Laura and I left to go check out the "Israeli West Bank Barrier," a ginormous concrete wall that Israel has constructed to separate Israel from Palestine. It's dotted with security cameras and guard towers. It looks like a maximum security prison perimeter. Israel argues that the wall is necessary in order to protect its citizens from Palestinian terrorist attacks. Palestinians call it the "Apartheid Wall." Some tourists and I were talking to a Palestinian who had his house next to the wall. He was complaining that he is scared to do anything because "big brother" is always watching. Either way, it's a tourist attraction now because the Palestinian side of it is covered with graffiti art. The famous graffiti artist, Banksy, has even left his mark. I was taking a picture of Laura in front of the wall, and all of a sudden, SMASH! A flaming bottle of gasoline blew up down the wall from me. Laura and I quickly moved away from the fire and turned around to see six or so Palestinians throwing makeshift "weapons" (some flaming bottles and rocks) over the wall to the Israeli side. After they unloaded their arsenal, they quickly retreated. Shortly thereafter a squad of soldiers from the Israeli army crossed over with riot gear on. Unfortunately I didn't get any good pictures because Laura and I were more concerned about our safety than being the next LIFE magazine photographer. But as we were walking later, we noticed that our eyes were tearing up and found out that the Israeli's had hit them with tear gas. The area we were in is a tourist area with tourist busses coming and going all the time. So it goes to show how real the conflict is... After the fiasco Laura and I headed straight back to Israel proper through an "immigration gate" in the wall and took the first bus back to Jerusalem. It was kind of funny because the only people walking through were a few "approved" Palestinians, a group of Christian pastors, and us. Probably one of the weirder border crossings we've had. And come to think of it, I'm glad we didn't tell anyone in Bethlehem that we were American.

item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: We booked a tour to go to Masada Fort and the Dead Sea for my birthday. The day started rough, with 3 Imodium pills, but quickly improved. Our tour was led in both Spanish and English; it was a small gift in itself to get to practice some Spanish. Our first stop was a bathroom break that happened to also be a Dead Sea cosmetics shop. After an infomercial and a dose of patience, we were on our way again. The drive led us past Qumran - where the Dead Sea Scrolls were found. Unfortunately we weren't able to explore the caves in hopes of finding more treasures. Masada Fort, perched on top of a steep desert cliff, can be hiked to in the blazing sun on foot or by effortless gondola ride. Our tour, thankfully, included the gondola ride. The fort was built by King Herod as an escape refuge in case any of his many enemies went after him. He ended up dying before utilizing the beautifully constructed desert utopia, complete with steam room, cold room, food storage, water cisterns to feed thousands, and temple. Hundreds of years later, when the Romans were taking over the area, a thousand Jews sought refuge in the abandoned fort. The Romans took three years to build a ramp to the compound and force their way in. The night before they arrived, however, the men inside killed their wives and children, before killing eachother. They decided it was better to die than be slaves of the Romans. Apparently there is a movie about the whole thing...I intend to find it. After all the time in the scorching sun we were ready to cover ourselves in mud and take a dip in the Dead Sea. It is 10x saltier than any ocean, making it impossible to sink. Literally. Mark and I had never been able to float, but found ourselves laughing and flailing in the water, amazed at our new buoyancy. You could stand straight up, feet not touching the bottom, and bob, head clear out of the water. The only bad part about all this fun is the terrible effects of the saltwater on your eyes and mouth. Everyone was careful to keep their heads dry to avoid, what felt like fire on your face. Mark and I both got a small taste of the salty water and did our best not to cry. There was also a nearby hot spring to warm up in. It was all wonderful. So wonderful. Exhausted after a long day, we showered and lay motionless in our room for awhile, recovering. Then Mark put on his schnazzy polo shirt and made me get into a dress for a nice dinner, recommended by Trip Advisor. We had delicious kebabs and red wine, the perfect way to end a wonderful birthday.
