item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: Jerusalem was our home base to make trips out to other parts of Israel. We found a hotel/hostel combo about a block from the Damascus Gate (north gate) of Old Jerusalem to call home base. There are eight gates into/out of the Old City. From here we spent our first two days exploring the old city. We visited the Mount of Olives, and also the Garden Tomb, our favorite place in Israel. The friendly people in the garden were a breath of fresh air from the blunt, harsh locals in town. Jesus is thought to have been crucified by nearby Skull Rock, a place easily visible from the ancient main road (the rock really does look just like a skull) and buried in a nearby cave. The next day we walked the Via Delarosa (the path Jesus took the day he was crucified). We also spent time at St. Anne's Church, which is beautiful and has perfect acoustics (as demonstrated by an epic tour group from Georgia - the country). Mark and I's solo was lacking, but it was amazing to hear the echo - it was like there were 6 of me! Nearby there are ruins that cover where the pool of Bethseda once was. It was really cool, too! We found free audio tours with maps courtesy of the Jerusalem Development Authority, which turned out to be surprisingly good. We loved learning the history of the old places - it really made ancient Biblical story locations come to life and help with the picture of geography and events in the early years BC. The downside was how strict and stark a lot of the churches felt. Many called for "silence" or felt unwelcoming or were putting excessive emphasis on things rather than God. "The rock where Jesus likely fell carrying his cross" or "The birthplace of Mary" had swarms of people gathered to touch and lay souvenirs and scarves on them, to soak up some holiness. At the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, where many think Jesus was killed and buried, the numerous religious groups that share the church often fight, causing police to be on call. This is why visiting the Garden Tomb was particularly refreshing. The staff who volunteer there focus on Jesus himself (historically and spiritually), rather than being caught up in religious tradition and superstition. Every morning we would eat the included breakfast at our hostel. It was great - pita bread, hummus, hard boiled eggs, salads, tea, coffee...the works. Lunch was a chicken shwarma or falafel lafa (giant Israeli burrito). Dinner was the same, accompanied by a ton of fresh fruit from the market. When you can get a kilo of the juiciest strawberries on the planet for $1.50, it's literally impossible to say no. On more side note: people walk all over in Israel with big guns. They aren't always wearing uniforms and often hold the trigger while they walk. I try not to to mess with anyone.

item.title: A Warm Greeting - Tel Aviv, Jerusalem, Israel
item.description: Our trip from Kathmandu, Nepal to Tel Aviv, Israel consisted of a 17-hour layover in Doha, Qatar, followed by the most intense security I have ever seen in Amman, Jordan. after over 35 hours of travel we were greeted at the Tel Aviv airport by Lev, a really nice Russian who has been living in Israel for the last 15 years. He and his girlfriend, Natalka, offered to host us in their downtown apartment. We were absolutely spoiled by a nice view from the enclosed balcony we called home, as well as
item.dc:creator: Laura
item.content:encoded: Our trip from Kathmandu, Nepal to Tel Aviv, Israel consisted of a 17-hour layover in Doha, Qatar, followed by the most intense security I have ever seen in Amman, Jordan. after over 35 hours of travel we were greeted at the Tel Aviv airport by Lev, a really nice Russian who has been living in Israel for the last 15 years. He and his girlfriend, Natalka, offered to host us in their downtown apartment. We were absolutely spoiled by a nice view from the enclosed balcony we called home, as well as home-cooked meals four times a day (yes, four). Natalka is Ukranian and an amazing cook. She made us Ukranian potato cakes, muffins, hummus, loads of broccoli and fresh vegetables, eggs, salads...the list goes on and on. We (and they) thought it was funny that they were Russian and Ukranian, considering recent current events. Both thought Putin should back off. Lev had to work at Dell during the days, and Natalka (who was a fashion designer in Ukraine) had computer design classes at a local college on Monday, so Mark and I explored on our own. We walked the half hour to the beach, marveled at all the jellyfish dead on the shore, and made our way toward Old Jaffa, the old area of Tel Aviv. We explored the "hipster" part of town, winding through flea markets and antique stores before wandering back home. That night we all went out for 'sabih' (sure I didn't spell that right), a vegetarian pita concoction made with eggplant. It was excellent. Lev and Natalka took us on a walking tour of their downtown area, including a visit to a a new missile defense system that was made to shoot down home-made rockets sent in the air from Palestine. Business as usual. After chowing down on some macadamia nut Hagan-Dazs ice cream, we fell easily into bed. The next day Mark and I were surprised with a beautiful breakfast. Also, Natalka told us that she could join us for the day. She took us through a different area of town in Old Jaffa, where she showed us the old streets, a floating tree suspended by cables, and one of oldest port in the world. Apparently, Jaffa Port is where Jonah took off in the "Jonah and the Whale" Bible story. Most importantly she showed us the best ice cream place in town, which is a strong contender for the best of our lives. After dinner we sat down to watch "The Barber of Siberia", a hilarious Russian movie, on Lev's giant projector screen. The next morning Mark and I took the bus to Jerusalem, with plans to meet our friends for some scuba diving at the Red Sea next week!

item.title: 35 hours of transit deserves a post - Doha, Qatar

item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded: From Nepal to Tel Aviv, we had to stop in Doha, Qatar and Amman, Jordan. We've heard rumors from other travelers that Qatar Airlines "hooks up" a hotel/food for their customers when they have an 8+ hour layover. Ours was 17 hours, so we had our fingers crossed! We landed and an airline representative told us to go upstairs and talk to the customer service desk who would give us a hotel. Woohoo! We were stoked. Once we got to the desk, we gave the lady our boarding cards and then she immediately started shaking her head. Uh oh... Apparently this sort of privilege is only honored if you take the two closest possible flights and it still amounts to an 8+ hour layover. Because we booked the cheapest option, this was not the case for us. 17 hours layover in the airport, ohhhhh yeaaaa..... We thought about leaving and checking out the city but the entry VISA was about $40 per person. Not really worth it for a few hours. From what we saw, the place looks like a small Dubai. They're dropping their dough on fancy hotels and expensive restaurants to try to encourage tourism before their oil money runs out. From Qatar we stopped in Amman, because Qatar doesn't fly directly to Israel (due to their relationship). In Amman, we were led by security down a bunch of back doors and corridors where we held in a small hallway and handed off to Israeli security. Their security is (understandably) rediculous. Each passenger is interviewed and their baggage is checked by hand. Laura and I felt like criminals and had to keep reminding ourselves that we didn't do anything wrong. I also noticed that they kept and Israeli guy in the line with us as we each waited our turn. He was looking around, profiling everybody to see if anyone looked like they were up to no good. Luckily, our long blonde hair didn't raise any flags. Finally, after a 35 minute flight, we landed in Tel Aviv! Holy Land Ho!
